Claim: Would we like to live in the world of Harry Potter?
The wizarding world is safer than the Muggle world.
The wizarding world has access to magical healthcare, which is far superior to Muggle healthcare.
There are many healing spells that can be used to treat diseases and injuries.
Episkey is a spell that heals relatively minor injuries such as broken noses and split lips.
Anapneo is a spell that clears a victim's airway if they are choking.

Vulnera Sanentur is a song-like incantation of a healing spell and counter-curse to the Sectumsempra spell, invented by Severus Snape. It has also been used by other wizards such as Dumbledore and Madam Pomfrey.
One does not have to be a Healer to use these spells, and poorly administered treatments can have disastrous results.
Gilderoy Lockhart attempts to mend Harry's arm but instead removes all the bones in the arm requiring painful treatment to regrow them.
Magical creatures can also be used to provide cures to some illnesses and injuries.
Phoenix tears have immense healing powers and are the only cure for Basilisk venom.
However phoenix tears are incredibly rare.
Murtlap Essence is used to soothe painful cuts and abrasions.
Mandrakes are a key ingredient in Restorative Draught, which cures those who have been petrified by a Basilisk.
There are some medicines only wizards have access to. One medicine can regrow bones.
There are also diseases and injuries that solely affect the magical population.
Dragon pox is a potentially fatal contagious disease that occurs in wizards and witches. It is similar to chicken pox but far deadlier.
Mis-Apparation can lead to Splinching.
Ron Weasley was badly injured after splinching away part of his upper arm while side-along apparating from Grimmauld Place.
Susan Bones splinched herself during her first Apparition lesson, temporarily losing a leg.

Magical healthcare also appears to be far more readily available than Muggle healthcare. There is no canonical evidence of people in the wizarding world suffering from long-term lack of care due to financial impediments.

The Weasley family is well known for being poor, but have no trouble accessing the best healthcare in the wizarding world, despite a lot of family members (Ron, Arthur, George) needing serious medical attention.
Wizard healing can cure any "normal" illness (any illness Muggles might contract).
Magical healing is only as good as the witch or wizard that administers the magic.
Many Muggle medicines rely on the skill of the person prescribing or administering them.
The wizarding world has magical hospitals staffed with experts at using healing magic.

While magical healing can cure "normal" illnesses, illness or injury of a magical nature can be much more dangerous. Broken bones can be easily cured, but the consequence of a curse or magic back-firing can be much more serious.
Even the best wizarding hospitals cannot cure many magical afflictions; for example, the insanity of Frank and Alice Longbottom.
The wizarding world does not seem to experience humanitarian crises like famines or disease epidemics.
Preventable diseases, lack of access to clean water, and famine are among the leading causes of death in the Muggle world.
In the wizarding world, everyone has the capacity to defend themselves against natural accidents or other types of dangers.
The ability to use simple stunning spells protects wizards against attacks by criminals.
Living in the wizarding world also means that attacks by wizard assailants, who are far more dangerous than Muggle assailants, are possible.
Attacks on Muggles by wizards are still possible and occur somewhat frequently, especially during the Wizarding Wars.

It is unfair to compare living situations between a peaceful Muggle world and a wizarding world at war. The lives of ordinary civilians in the Muggle or wizarding world could be at great risk from a host of threats if their nations go to war.
The powers of Apparition, levitation and summoning of objects, and Transfiguration can be used to avoid natural dangers like natural disasters, being lost in the wild, and so forth.
Wizards can use spells to protect themselves from car crashes, falls from heights, and injuries.
The wizarding world also contains more natural hazards than the Muggle world.
The wizarding world contains all sorts of deadly magical creatures like giant spiders, giants, and hippogriffs.
The Muggle world similarly contains deadly wild creatures, but these animals can largely be avoided in both the wizarding and Muggle world.
Giants tend to live in isolated areas such as mountains; dragons live in isolated deserts or other areas.
The wizarding world contains deadly flora like the Whomping Willow.
Not everyone in the wizarding world is a competent wizard and so not everyone can competently defend themselves.
Squibs, non-magical people with magical parentage, cannot use magic and are therefore defenceless in the wizarding world.
Wizards can easily Apparate away from positions of danger.
The act of Apparition in a state where the wizard is under pressure and is unable to fully concentrate can be terribly painful and dangerous.
Apparition is an advanced skill that can only be completed by fully trained wizards.
Long-distance Apparition is considered dangerous, thus wizards still rely on other means for inter-continental travel.
It is still incredibly convenient to be able to Apparate anywhere within a country.
Only short travel distances are necessary to escape danger.
Wizards who are too young to Apparate would probably be accompanied most of the time by someone who can Apparate away with them.
In Britain, a wizard or witch must be at least 17 to have an Apparition license. Many people younger than this don't travel with an adult.
An Anti-Apparition Charm can be used to make it impossible for Apparition to occur in certain places, as is the case with Hogwarts.
Hogwarts is a generally safe environment; Apparition is possible in most environments that contain potential dangers.
Hogwarts is more dangerous than a Muggle boarding school.
Following Dumbledore's death, Hogwarts was essentially overtaken by Death Eaters, who taught classes in the Dark Arts and bullied students.
The Carrow siblings were in charge of discipline at Hogwarts and their detentions included using the Cruciatus Curse on students, and corporal punishment through beatings.
Death Eater Alecto Carrow was put in charge of a compulsory Muggle Studies class that taught that Muggles are inferior to wizards.
In the Muggle world, oppressive regimes such as North Korea also control their schools in an authoritarian way. This is a feature of dictatorships and not the wizarding world.
Hogwarts teachers are irresponsible and contribute to a dangerous and unhealthy school environment.
Potions that resemble psychoactive drugs, such as Felix Felicis, are available in Hogwarts and even given to students by teachers.
Hogwarts is a place where bullying is rampant and teachers seem to care little.
When Hogwarts students are annoyed at one another, they often resort to hexes or even punches.
Harry Potter once used the curse Sectumsempra on Draco Malfoy without knowing what it would do. It caused serious damage in the form of cuts and wounds.
Even some of the greatest heroes of the First Wizarding War were bullies at Hogwarts.
Numerous teachers turn a blind eye to bullying, for example Snape and Mad-Eye Moody.
Some Hogwarts students have been known to use dark magic on one another for fun.
Dumbledore acted irresponsibly by appointing Rubeus Hagrid as the Care of Magical Creatures professor at Hogwarts.
Hagrid was appointed even though he was under-qualified to teach.
Hagrid was appointed despite the availability of a more qualified, popular and better teacher, Professor Grubby-Plank.
Hagrid was appointed to teach a dangerous Care of Magical Creatures class despite never having completed his own education.
Though Hagrid's classes were sometimes well planned, he also had his students study flobberworms for an entire term.
Having served as Game Keeper at Hogwarts for decades, Hagrid had interacted with enough dangerous creatures to be qualified enough to teach students at the time of his appointment.
Hagrid shared a unique bond with dangerous creatures that made him a great Game Keeper, but not necessarily a good teacher.
Hagrid, though a great person, was known for his love of dangerous creatures and put the safety of his students at risk while teaching his classes.
Hagrid made his Fourth Year students raise Blast-Ended Skrewts, dangerous hybrid creatures of his own creation, without fully being aware of how dangerous they were, or what they ate.
Hagrid introduced Third Year students to Hippogriffs in their first lesson, and one of them injured a student.

Draco Malfoy was only injured because he was too arrogant to listen to Hagrid's instructions. This is largely Malfoy's fault and not Hagrid's, as Harry Potter was able to interact with the Hippogriff without being harmed.
Draco Malfoy was thirteen years old at the time. Thirteen-year-olds should not be put in situations where they could be maimed if they don't follow instructions correctly.

Thirteen year old students, both wizarding and Muggle, are involved in many activities endorsed by schools and parents, for example, quidditch, wrestling, boxing, football, cricket and rugby where they risk serious injury to themselves or their peers if they do not follow instructions correctly.
Hogwarts students are given access to dangerous levels of control over one another when they are taught about love potions and polyjuice potion.
The teachers are not well screened; twice during Harry's tenure at the school the Defence Against the Dark Arts Teacher was working directly for Voldemort.
Hogwarts teachers have been known to send students to the Forbidden Forest as detention and, on one occasion, turn a student into a ferret as punishment.
Dolores Umbridge's detention sessions consisted of physical torture, and left Harry Potter with permanent scars.

The use of the black quill would have been illegal given that corporal punishment is not a generally accepted practice at Hogwarts and Harry was repeatedly advised to report Professor Umbridge's actions to Professor McGonagall.
It was irresponsible for Dumbledore to appoint Remus Lupin, a known werewolf, as a teacher without letting the students or their parents know about his condition.
If Dumbledore had followed this process, Lupin would never have been given the job due to unreasonable prejudices of the wizarding population. This would be unjust for a man of Lupin's ability.
The stigma against werewolves is regrettable but a school full of children is not the best place to hire one in the first place.
The sequence of events which led to Lupin not taking his potion was unlikely and impossible to predict. Dumbledore had good reason to assume Lupin would take his potion without concern.
Dumbledore knew better than anyone the relationship Lupin and Sirius shared since their childhood, and that Sirius wanted to come to Hogwarts to speak with Harry Potter.
Dumbledore could have used his sizable influence and powers of persuasion to get Lupin a job outside of Hogwarts, or kept Lupin at Hogwarts after having done due diligence toward his students.
The view towards werewolves means that Lupin would have struggled to find a job anywhere.
Parents or students do not have an overwhelming right to know all the immutable characteristics of Professors who teach at an educational institution.

Parents and students do have a right to information that might directly undermine the health and safety of students on campus. Remus Lupin was a liability the night he did not take his Wolfsbane potion and could have easily maimed or killed a student during his transformation.
Teachers are very biased in the way they award house points: some such as Snape tend to favour their own house and punish the others.

Dumbledore awarded enough points to Gryffindor to make them win the House Cup instead of Slytherin even though the term had officially ended. On the other hand, McGonagall did not take away any points from Harry and Ron after they crashed the flying car into the Whomping Willow, since the term had not yet started.
This is particularly true as most teachers went through Hogwarts themselves and thus have a natural bias toward the house they were in.
Many Hogwarts teachers, such as Professor McGonagall and Professor Flitwick, seem to be fair, and also care about the wellbeing of their students.
Professors Flitwick, Sprout and Lupin are all knowledgable teachers, who are encouraging and supportive of their students in classes and seek to provide a good wizarding education.
Professor McGonagall remains at Hogwarts when it is being run by Snape and the Death Eaters, and does her best to support and protect students.
Quidditch is more dangerous than Muggle sports.
Players are not allowed to be substituted in the case of injury which can incentivise them to play on despite being seriously injured rather than leaving their team short a player.
Players can get fatigued because Quidditch matches have no set time limits and can go on for weeks.
During a Quidditch World Cup match that lasted for days, the normal rule of not being allowed to substitute players was waived to allow players to get some sleep.
Quidditch occurs on unstable flying platforms at great heights, and contains fast-flying balls that attempt to hit players.
The sorts of injuries that Quidditch can cause (broken bones; falls from brooms) can be fixed with magic (magical healing or levitation charms).
Bludgers are potentially lethal, and no practically available magic is capable of resurrection.
Quidditch is a voluntary activity, and played only by a relatively small percentage of wizards.
Certain popular Muggle sports are very dangerous, like American football, which causes lasting brain damage in a very high percentage of players.
99% of deceased NFL players' brains that were donated to scientific research showed chronic traumatic encephalopathy, a neurodegenerative brain disease.
There is evidence that there is a link between American football and concussions.
The curriculum at Hogwarts seems to care little about the safety of students.
At Hogwarts, teenagers are taught in class how to utilize deadly magic, work with plants whose scream can kill and brew chemical weapons-level potions.
Hogwarts students are taught how to duel, which is essentially the Muggle equivalent of a fight to the death.
Students are only taught to duel in response to a specific threat at one time. In general the practice is banned at Hogwarts.
Duels are not necessarily fights to the death, it is seemingly rare that someone dies in one.

The parties involved usually agree to limits on spells to be used during the duel. This indicates that duelists generally agree not to use particularly dangerous or illegal spells, such as the Unforgivable Curses.
Even the most famous and high stakes of duels, such as that between Dumbledore and Grindelwald in 1945, finishes in defeat rather than death.
This is perhaps because Dumbledore used to be in love with Grindelwald and made the conscious decision to spare the latter's life.
The Hogwarts teachers hosted The Triwizard Tournament in 1994, even though the tournament was renowned for being extremely dangerous, and had previously resulted in the death of its participants.
Cedric Diggory, one of the Hogwarts champions, was killed after completing the third task.
This was not the fault of the competition, but the result of Barty Crouch Jr. turning the Triwizard Cup into a portkey, which transported Cedric and Harry Potter to the graveyard in Little Hangleton.

The tasks at the Hogwarts Triwizard Tournament included requiring champions to battle a dragon, rescue their friends from the bottom of the Black Lake, and find their way through a maze full of obstacles and dangers.
Participation is voluntary; the school does not force any student to expose himself/herself to the tournament's dangers.
Students are pressured to participate by the promise of fame, glory and a thousand Galleons cash prize. The decision to participate is coerced at best.
Younger generations are more likely to be obsessed with becoming famous than others. This is also a coercive force in entering the Tournament.
Young people are more likely to be influenced by the prospect of winning a large sum of money.
The thousand Galleons prize money was the primary reason why Fred and George Weasley were interested in the Triwizard Tournament.
Those reasons are similar to the reasons many Muggles choose to enter into sporting competitions.
The difference in Muggle sporting competitions is that the potential for significant harm is miniscule compared to the Triwizard Tournament.
Only very few students are allowed to enter, and the selection process is rigorous, so the chance of being pressured into the tournament is low.
As the degree of selectivity and the rigorous selection process are a part of the legend surrounding the Triwizard Tournament, they are partly responsible for coercing the students to enter.

Harry Potter did not put his name in the Goblet and yet he was selected as a Hogwarts champion. He therefore had to compete despite not choosing it for himself, and being younger than the rules require entrants to be.
This was merely the result of Barty Crouch Junior's manipulation of the Goblet of Fire and would not have happened under normal circumstances.
Young students cannot reasonably be expected to foresee the long term implications of such decisions. It is the responsibility of the faculty to limit access to dangerous choices in the first place.

According to the revised rules, only students over the age of seventeen were allowed to enter or compete in the tournament. Seventeen-year-olds are legally considered adults in the wizarding world and can make decisions for themselves.
Other sports competitions in schools are also dangerous yet generally accepted. An example is high school football in the United States which is believed to cause brain trauma in many players.
Second year Hogwarts students are required to study Mandrakes using only earmuffs for protection, despite the fact that the scream of a baby Mandrake can render a student unconscious for hours.
The building itself is unsafe.
The staircases move, even while students are walking on them.
The castle contains many tall towers which pose safety risks.
The staircase to the Owlery Tower is outdoors meaning there is a risk of slipping on ice in colder months.
The Astronomy Tower is seven storeys above ground and is surrounded by a parapet. This is a safety risk as falling from the tower would almost certainly result in death.
The tower is generally not allowed to be accessed outside of classes.

Both Gryffindor and Ravenclaw's house dormitories are located in towers seven storeys above ground. If a student fell from a window in one of these towers the fall would almost certainly result in their death.
This could easily be resolved by putting grills on the windows.
This risk is not significantly different from multi-storey schools and buildings in general in the Muggle world.
There are secret entrances into the castle that aren't properly monitored.

Twice during Harry Potter's time at Hogwarts, Death Eaters managed to invade Hogwarts and battles took place. First there was the Battle of the Astronomy Tower, when Dumbledore died. Second there was the Battle of Hogwarts that led to the downfall of Voldemort.
Draco Malfoy, a student at Hogwarts, managed to easily arrange for Death Eaters to enter the school through use of a magical cabinet.
Hogwarts was probably safer in this situation than Muggle schools would have been due to its magical protection including gargoyles.
Both instances of Death Eaters getting into Hogwarts took place during the Second Wizarding War. This represents extraordinary circumstances; hardly any school would be safe in wartime.

This is especially true in the case of the Wizarding War. Since Hogwarts was a very integral part of Tom Riddle's development as a wizard and quest for power, Hogwarts became a focal point during the war.
Hogwarts has a series of protective enchantments placed on it which protect it from external dangers.
Dangerous items can be smuggled into the castle via Owl Post.
Fred and George offered a 'discreet' mailing service for items from their joke shop, including love potions. Such potions would be disguised as ordinary medicines.
This is believed by Hermione to be how Romilda Vane managed to get a love potion into the castle.
Dangerous items can be smuggled into Muggle boarding schools via Muggle post.
There was no particular magical protection on the gates of Hogwarts until Voldemort's return.
The gates did not stop or prevent cursed items.
After the Ministry of Magic acknowledged Voldemort's return, Filch was forced to manually search students' luggage upon their return to Hogwarts.
Harry was able to bring the cursed necklace that Katie Bell touched all the way up to the castle from Hogsmeade unopposed until Filch stopped them.
Hogwarts’ gates were bewitched by Albus Dumbledore after Voldemort's return so they couldn’t be unlocked through magical means. Anti-intruder jinxes of some sort were also put on them.
Prior to that, students could simply walk through the gates, with a brief security check at the door into the castle.
It is perfectly reasonable to have a security level proportionate to the threat. It would be unnecessary to have some of these measures in place in times of total peace.

The same logic is regularly employed at Muggle centres. For example, even though increased security would always be safer, airports tend to increase their security only in response to specific threats.
During times of concern about safety, Hogwarts has hired security trolls, who are specially trained to guard places and objects.
In 1993, Dumbledore hired security trolls to guard the Fat Lady's portrait after she was attacked by Sirius Black who was attempting to enter Gryffindor Tower.
Muggle boarding schools rarely, if ever, experience such threat that they need to hire additional security.
Hogwarts has a large staff of professors who can more effectively protect students from potential dangers, because they know magic.
Hogwarts has numerous portraits whose occupants fulfill the roles of mobile surveillance cameras and alarm system.
The portrait of the Fat Lady refused to grant then-suspected mass-murderer Sirius Black access to the Gryffindor Tower when he broke into Hogwarts.
The varying personalities of the inhabitants of portraits make them unreliable. Sir Cadogan allowed Sirius Black to enter Gryffindor Tower, potentially endangering the lives of students.
It is impossible to know if all of the subjects of the paintings in Hogwarts are well-meaning or trustworthy.
Hogwarts is physically isolated making external threats less likely.
External threats to Hogwarts are most likely to be magical in nature. Hogwarts' surroundings are easy to get to through a number of magical means.
Hogwarts was known as the safest place in wizarding Britain to hide something.
This may have been its reputation however in reality this was not the case.
Voldemort hid a horcrux (the diadem of Ravenclaw) in Hogwarts thinking it would never be found. It only took Harry a matter of hours to find and destroy it.
The Philosopher's Stone is protected only by enchantments and puzzles that three eleven year olds can break through.
Hogwarts being a safe place to hide an object does not necessarily mean it is also a safe place for students.
The wizarding world is more prone to internal warfare than the Muggle world.
Due to the lack of a distinction between military and non-military wizards, wizarding wars are a threat to all wizards.
On average, about 50% of casualties in Muggle wars are civilians, so these wars are still a threat to all Muggles.
The First Wizarding War, Second Wizarding War, and Global Wizarding War were all fought within the space of 50 years and resulted in large numbers of wizarding casualties.
The Muggle world experiences large-scale wars frequently.
Everyone carries wands, which are the wizard equivalent of guns (wizards describe guns as metal wands Muggles kill each other with) which makes the potential for escalation and harm greater.
Students are taught about the Unforgivable Curses, which are used to torture, control and kill people. These are spells that they learn about and then could use.
Students at Hogwarts were only taught the Unforgivable Curses in one year, because their teacher happened to be a Death Eater in disguise. This would not be a general occurrence.
Barty Crouch Jr, disguised as Mad-Eye Moody, told his class that the Unforgivable Curses were not on the official syllabus as the Ministry of Magic did not want them taught.
The Unforgivable Curses are illegal in the wizarding world and their use is grounds for immediate life imprisonment in Azkaban Prison.
Unforgivable Curses are not monitored.
The Ministry was not aware that their own official, Barty Crouch Senior, was put under the Imperius Curse by Lord Voldemort.
The only way the Ministry of Magic can detect the use of Unforgivable Curses is by using 'Priori Incantatem' on a potential criminal's wand.
Harry Potter used the Cruciatus Curse on Amycus Carrow at Hogwarts and the Imperius Curse to control Travers when breaking into Gringotts. He was neither punished for using them nor even detected.
These spells were cast just before the Second Wizarding War when the Ministry of Magic was run by Death Eaters who used the Unforgivable Curses extensively.

Knowing Mad-Eye Moody, it would not have been out of character for him to teach the students the Unforgiveable Curses. One of the reasons Barty Crouch Jr was able to go undetected for so long is because of his very convincing impression of Mad-Eye.
The ease of escalation is counterbalanced by the fact that bystanders can easily intervene to stop a fight, for example by Stunning or disarming participants.
This logic is equally applied in support of gun rights in the USA, yet the presence of guns does not improve safety.
Guns are lethal weapons that are difficult to use. All wizards are familiar with magic, which can be easily used nonlethally to prevent a fight.
Wizards can use a shield charm to protect themselves against the majority of curses.
If your attacker catches you off guard you may not have time to cast a shield charm to protect yourself.
The element of surprise gives an unfair advantage to individuals in Muggle combat as well. It is not something exclusive to wizarding duels.

It's not accurate to say that wands are the wizard equivalent of guns. Guns have one use only, and that is to harm. Wizards can use their wands to do many different things, such as protecting or healing someone, repairing objects, creating light or water and so on.
The most commonly used offensive spells (like Stupefy or Petrificus Totalus) are harmless. People rarely use spells that are bodily harmful or deadly.
While not deadly, being rendered unconscious or immobile can still cause a wizard significant harm as they are left completely defenseless.

The wizarding world is just as dangerous as the muggle world, maybe even more so as it has more ways to kill someone when the wizard is knowledgeable with things from the muggle world, as Harry Potter and Hermione Granger do.
The wizarding world has Polyjuice Potion, the Imperius Curse, and numerous other charms, curses, and potions that can make it unclear if someone is indeed themself and/or acting on their own accord.
Even if these options are present, they are not frequently used. So they do not constitute a significant danger.
Thief's Downfall is a charm that lifts enchantments, including the Imperius Curse and the effects of Polyjuice potions.
Magic is often dangerous to the user.
There are documented cases of flawed or broken wands causing spells to backfire on their users.
Gilderoy Lockhart's attempt at using the memory charm with a broken wand backfired on himself and he ended up in St Mungo's Hospital with severe memory loss.

Ronald Weasley’s wand started malfunctioning after he broke it. When he attempted to hex Draco Malfoy, the spell backfired and caused Ron to vomit slugs. Ron also injured Seamus Finnigan by mistake during the first meeting of the Duelling Club.
Wands are dangerous objects, and similar objects like guns, knives or machinery could cause serious injury or even death in the Muggle world if mishandled or used when damaged.
The Ministry of Magic has a Department of Magical Accidents and Catastrophes, suggesting they have to deal with both on a somewhat frequent basis.
Hogwarts students are banned from using magic outside of the supervised environment of the classroom.
These rules are flouted by the vast majority of students and, in many cases, teachers wilfully fail to enforce them.
When Hermione Granger's teeth were enlarged by Draco Malfoy's hex, Professor Snape openly refused to acknowledge it or punish the culprit.
Hermione Granger successfully brewed polyjuice potion in a girls bathroom without being caught or punished. She, Harry Potter and Ron Weasley all took the potion.
Professor Slughorn saw Ginny hex Zacharias Smith on the Hogwarts Express and, instead of punishing her, invited her to join his club.
Magic has many practical uses that can increase the efficiency of day-to-day life.
Wizards can easily travel across large distances using magical methods of transportation.
Portkeys are regular objects, such as cups or shoes, that have been enchanted in such a way that they take anyone who touches them to a predetermined location.
Portkeys are convenient for those who cannot Apparate, who wish to travel by day, and whose destination does not have a fireplace.
Portkeys carry inherent security risks, since they can be activated by mere touch.

Barty Crouch Jr. bewitches the Triwizard Cup to make it a Portkey. When Harry Potter and Cedric Diggory unwittingly touch it, they are transported to a deserted graveyard of Voldemort's choice where Cedric is subsequently murdered, and Harry narrowly escapes the same fate.
Portkeys are not necessarily recognizable as such and can therefore be activated by accident and without intention.
Portkeys have to be approved by the Ministry of Magic before they can be used.
The sensation of traveling by Portkey is decidedly uncomfortable, and healers recommend that the elderly, pregnant, and infirm avoid them.
A lot of wizarding transportation options are magical improvements on Muggle transportation systems.
Cars and motorcycles can be magically altered to suit the needs of the magical community.
Arthur Weasley enchanted a Ford Anglia to make it fly.
Sirius Black enchanted a motorcycle with a sidecar to make it fly and then used it extensively. It was then handed over to Hagrid.
The Ministry of Magic has cars that look like exactly like Muggle cars but are enchanted to accommodate a much larger number of people.
The Knight Bus is an enchanted bus system that helps transport stranded members of the magical community across different parts of Britain.

Magical boats can take magical shortcuts to other waterways. For example, the Durmstrang Ship, which is a magical ship that can travel underwater, is used by the Durmstrang Institute to transport its staff and students. It appears from the depths of Hogwarts lake, even though the lake is not physically connected to other seas or rivers.
Vanishing Cabinets which are made in pairs help users transport themselves across distances by entering one cabinet and exiting through its sister cabinet.

Vanishing Cabinets can penetrate protective enchantments placed around buildings. Even though Hogwarts was fortified to protect its students, Malfoy was able to use a pair of Vanishing Cabinets, one in Borgin and Burkes and the other in the Room of Requirement, to let Death Eaters into Hogwarts.
There is a dangerous aspect to the use of Vanishing Cabinets: if either one of them is broken, the person utilizing them can get stuck in limbo.
Graham Montague was trapped in a Vanishing Cabinet for a day after he was shoved in by Fred and George; his Apparition out left him disorientated for weeks.
The Floo Network connects all the fireplaces in the wizarding world.
The Floo Network can be used to transport children, the elderly and the infirm.
The use of Floo Powder has a very small margin for error and is quite dangerous.
Travelers also cannot afford to fidget or panic because that could lead to their coming out at the wrong fireplace.
The name of the destination has to be pronounced perfectly, or else the user could end up at the wrong fireplace.
Harry Potter mispronounces Diagon Alley as 'Diagonally' when using Floo Powder for the first time. He then ends up in the notorious Knockturn Alley.
Travelers must keep their elbows tucked in to avoid banging them on the passing fireplaces. Thus, a slight error could cause serious injury.

Violet Tillyman was a witch who lived in the 19th century. In 1855, she was deemed to be missing after she left her home via the Floo Network, but failed to reach her intended destination. She resurfaced twenty years later in what came to be known as "the most notorious case of accidental misdirection" in the history of the Floo Network.
Many forms of Muggle transport are dangerous if the user is not careful. Cars can kill in an instant.
Transportation by Floo Powder is much slower than other methods as it requires physical access to a fireplace connected to the rest of the network.
The Floo Network is easily accessible to even untrained wizards or other members of the magical community like Squibs who cannot use magic, as it does not require a license or training to use.

Even though flying carpets are now banned in Britain, due to being defined as a Muggle Artifact by the Registry of Proscribed Charmable Objects, they are popular modes of transportation for wizards in other parts of the world.
A common method of transportation for the wizarding community is the use of broomsticks.
There is even the capacity to play sport on broomsticks as Quidditch is a very popular game.
Travel by broomstick seems very dangerous, as falling off would mean likely death.
Much as with motorbikes in the Muggle world, the traveler is unlikely to fall off their broom due to inertia.
Trained wizards who travel on broomsticks usually carry their wands and would probably be able to levitate themselves to safety, even on the off chance they did fall off.
The Levitation Charm is elementary magic taught to first year students at Hogwarts.
Broomsticks are not feasible as a method of very long-distance travel, since people would become tired, or harmed by lengthy exposure to cold winds.
Weather-related issues could easily be alleviated with protective spells.
The Atmospheric Charm can be used to modify the weather.
Apparition is the process of teleportation by which one can disappear in one place and appear almost instantaneously at another. Apparition is also free, and therefore accessible.
A wizard Apparating on their own can only travel to a location they have visually seen before, as Apparition requires mentally picturing the desired destination.
The wizarding world also takes advantage of magical creatures to help with their transportation needs.
The Beauxbatons Carriage is a light-blue carriage pulled by a dozen winged horses used to transport the staff and students of Beauxbatons Academy of Magic.
Thestrals are horse-like creatures that can be ridden or trained to draw carriages.
Dumbledore's Army rode on thestrals to get to the Ministry of Magic in 1996.
Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry use thestral drawn carriages to take their students to school from the train station.
Thestrals are rarely used as methods of transportation due to their reputation as omens of evil and their somewhat dreadful and even distasteful appearance.
The Ministry of Magic has classified thestrals as "dangerous" so only experienced wizards or witches should handle them.
Wizards and witches that live in areas not protected against Muggles are forced by law to perform Disillusionment Charms on their Thestrals regularly.
Thestrals are particularly difficult to use for transportation as they can only be seen by those who have been truly touched by death. For everyone else, they are invisible.
A hippogriff is a magical creature that wizards can train and ride on in a manner similar to how Muggles ride on horses.
Hippogriffs are excellent companions, and are fiercely protective of those who have gained their trust.
Buckbeak attacked Snape to protect Harry during the Battle of the Astronomy Tower, and led the Hogwarts thestrals into the Battle of Hogwarts.
Keeping a hippogriff is inconvenient as it is legally required to cast a Disillusionment Charm daily on it in order to keep it hidden from Muggles.
The International Statute of Wizarding Secrecy rules out the use of hippogriffs for purposes of personal transportation.
Hippogriffs are dangerous and difficult to interact with as they have to be dealt with using a particular etiquette.
Hippogriffs are very proud creatures and can react violently when they feel offended or disrespected: when Malfoy verbally insults Buckbeak the Hippogriff, for example, Buckbeak attacks him.
The Ministry of Magic has certain limitations and rules regarding use of magical creatures as a form of transport.
Most forms of transportation are regulated and supervised by The Department of Magical Transportation which fines witches and wizards who transgress the rules.
This is no different to the Muggle systems of transportation, which are also governed by rules and potential punishments.
The culmination of these efficiencies is that wizards and witches can spend more of their time doing meaningful things, such as investing in relationships.
There are many useful and simple spells that wizards learn and are able to use frequently.
The Summoning Charm can be used to summon objects to oneself across physical space without actually having to go find and retrieve them.

Capacious Extremis, the undetectable extension charm, increases the inner dimensions of an object, while leaving the outer dimensions unchanged, and also makes the content lighter. It makes packing and storage much easier.

Because of the potential for infractions under the International Statue of Secrecy, the Ministry of Magic has laid down strict guidelines stating that capacity enhancement is not for private use, but only for the production of objects (such as school trunks).
The Levitation Charm can be used to move objects by making them fly.
Lumos is a spell which sends light from the tip of a wand, to be used as a torch.
The charm Reparo can be used to easily fix things.
Wizards and witches use their magic to do things like clean their house and cook meals.
Tergeo is a cleaning spell, used to clean things such as grease off surfaces.
The Scouring Charm is used to clean household items.
The divide between the magical world and the Muggle world means that the wizarding world lacks most modern technology and is, at times, archaic.
The wizarding world still uses gas lamps and candles.
It is advantageous for the wizarding community to use gas lamps instead of electricity because of the command wizards can exercise on fire by using magic, for example, through the Fire Making Charm.
The wizarding world still uses quills, ink, and parchment scrolls.
Using magic means that the use of these objects can be very easy and ensures they do not require upgrading. For example, quills can be charmed to self-ink and write on their own.
Paper, pens and ball point refills are in no way a meaningful upgrade from the use of parchment, quills and ink respectively.
The wizard world still relies on fires and fireplaces for heating.
The increasing technological divide reduces the ability of wizards to interact and coexist with the Muggle world, since they do not know how to use ubiquitous technologies.
Wizards use owl post, which is a slow and inefficient form of communication.
Owls can find a particular person no matter where in the world they are.
The wizarding world has several other ways of communicating with each other that are much faster.
Portraits in the wizarding world can be used to communicate with other witches and wizards.
A Patronus can be used as a means of secure communication by delivering messages in the voice of the caster.
The only people who currently know of this ability are members of the Order of the Phoenix.

A fire-call is a specialised use of the Floo network, whereby a witch or wizard simply inserts their head into a connected and Floo-prepared fireplace, and their head is transported to the fireplace of the person with whom they wish to speak.

The principal limitation of full-body transportation by Floo network also applies to this form of communication: fire-calls require physical access to a fireplace connected to the rest of the network, so it is not always feasible.
The wizarding world's methods of communication (such as owls) seem largely inferior, or at least more complex, than internet based communications.
The wizarding world is unfamiliar with electronics, like television, telephones, and computers.
Avoidance of Muggle devices is cultural. The magical community prides itself on not needing the many devices that Muggles have created to do what can be done by magic.
The wizarding world's non-use of Muggle devices is in fact largely down to practical difficulties.
Magic interferes with electric energy and thus makes it, for the most part, impossible for wizards to use modern technology. This is a highly impractical side-effect.
Electronic devices do not work within the grounds of Hogwarts.

Magical methods seem to advance slowly, if at all, whereas technology has grown exponentially over the last several centuries. The comparative advantages of magic look likely to erode into the future.
Magic is scientifically impossible in the Muggle world. That is a comparative advantage that time will never erode.
Many technologies that Muggles use are not necessary for wizards as they can utilize magic.
Some advancements in Muggle medicine are primitive compared to the magical techniques employed by Healers.
Wizards would still benefit from the use of technology such as computers, and systems such as Google to get easy and quick access to information.
Arthur Weasley's greatest ambition was to figure out how Muggle planes fly. This could be easily accomplished with Google.
Students at Hogwarts only learn using textbooks. It would be much more efficient for them to have access to reading and research materials online.
Muggles need new technology to overcome the limits of old technology. Wizards can just use magic to overcome any limitations.
Wizards adopted some technology from Muggles, such as plumbing and cameras.
The wizarding world is limited in some very important respects.
Employment opportunities are extremely limited.
The majority of people in wizarding Britain work at Hogwarts, in the Ministry of Magic or in a wizarding shop. Opportunities are far more diverse in the Muggle world.
A significant number of Muggles in Britain work in the public sector, and retail is the largest source of private sector employment, suggesting opportunities are not all that diverse.
There appear to be very few wizards involuntarily out of work.
Quidditch seems to be the only popular sport in the wizarding world: this is highly limiting to wizards and witches interested in sport.
This is especially true for those witches and wizards who want a sport that is safe.
There is wizarding chess and gobstones for those who want an alternative to Quidditch.
There are only eleven established wizarding schools throughout the world.
Many of magic's practical uses just imitate what Muggles already have available through technology, and in many cases are inferior.
Wizarding media is largely confined to books, slightly-animated pictures, and oddities such as a Pensieve. In contrast Muggle media includes on-demand access to movies, music, and video games.

For all the practical uses of magic, it does not seem to increase the quality of life of wizards relative to the Muggle population. For example, the Weasleys, as a relatively poor wizarding family, still struggle to get by in some respects.
While there is still wealth inequality in the wizarding world, it seems as if the average standard of living is still superior.
Magic opens a lot of interesting possibilities.
There are a number of mythical creatures which live in the wizarding world.
Sphinxes come from Egypt.
Sphinxes are highly intelligent and used by witches and wizards to stand guard. They can be dangerous when what they guard is threatened.
Unicorns are found throughout forests in northern Europe.
Unicorn blood has the ability to save the drinker from death, no matter how close they are to it.
Voldemort used unicorn blood to sustain his life when he was occupying Quirrell's body, which itself was dying as a result of being shared by Voldemort's fragmented soul.
The act of slaying a unicorn to drink its blood is said to curse the drinker and provide them only a half-life.
If the act of killing the unicorn for its blood is the source of such a curse, then there are various ways to avoid inducing such a curse while still getting to drink unicorn blood and extend life.
One could pay some poor schmuck, perhaps a muggle, to kill the unicorn and get cursed while you get to enjoy the fruits of their labour.

You could kill a unicorn for another reason - perhaps magically altering your own memories before the hunt, so you're honest in this other motive - and "just happen" to also bottle and store most of its blood.
You could keep a population of unicorns under constant observation, wait for one to die without your involvement, and show up immediately to drain the blood from its still-warm corpse.
One could bleed a unicorn without killing it.
Unicorn blood is strictly controlled by the Ministry of Magic, making it incredibly hard to get access to.
Unicorn hair is used as cores for wands.
Phoenixes are fascinating and immensely helpful.
Phoenixes can carry immensely heavy loads, their tears have healing powers, and when their bodies begin to fail, they burst into flame and are reborn from the ashes.
Phoenix tail feathers are used as cores for wands.
Phoenixes are very rare and most wizards will never see or interact with one.
While quite dangerous, dragons exist in the wild.

Dragon bodyparts (such as powdered horn and organs) are important for potions, dragon heartstrings are used by Ollivander for wand cores, and there are twelve uses for dragon blood (including oven cleaner).
Dragons are usually ill-tempered and can kill a person instantly.
Some of the magical creatures are awful and undesirable.
Acromantulas are giant spiders that are intelligent and highly dangerous.
Acromantulas have been known to eat people.
Despite Hagrid's close bond with Aragog, the colony tried to eat Hagrid as soon as Aragog died.
Aragog's colony tried to eat Ron and Harry in their second year.
The fire crab is a large, turtle-like crab creature native to Fiji that is highly dangerous.
They are able to defend themselves by shooting flames from their rear ends when threatened.
Rubeus Hagrid managed to get manticores and fire crabs to breed, indicating that it is possible to keep oneself safe while interacting with them.

The manticore is one of the wizarding world's most dangerous creatures. It has a human-like head, a lion's body, and a scorpion's tail with a stinger that causes instant death. A manticore's skin repels all known charms, so it is effectively hard to subdue a manticore with magic.
The Blast-Ended Skrewt is a hybrid creature bred by Rubeus Hagrid by crossing manticores and fire crabs.
Hagrid began breeding the Skrewts at the beginning of the school year, and had several hundred. By the following year, he only had one left as they often cannibalised each other.

Adult Skrewts grow ten feet long, and are incredibly dangerous and lethal. They resemble giant scorpions with stingers curled over their backs. Their shiny armour deflects most spells and they use their blasts to propel themselves at a foe.
The males have stingers and the females have suckers on their body to suck blood.
The Basilisk is a giant serpent, also known as the King of Serpents. It is a creature bred by dark wizards.

Basilisk venom is so powerful that it can kill a person within minutes, making the person drowsy and blurry-visioned before they die. It has a very long lasting effect which still remains potent even up to five years or more after the snake has died.
It is far too easy to breed a Basilisk: you simply hatch a chicken egg from beneath a toad.
Given how rare they are, it may not be that easy to breed Basilisks.
Looking a Basilisk directly in the eye immediately kills the victim, while indirect contact leaves them in a state of paralysis.
Mountain trolls are strong, unpredictable, violent, and stupid.

A Non-Human Spiritous Apparition (a non-being) is a type of magical creature that is created from and sustained by human emotions and is a mystery even to wizards. Being amortal, they are not born and cannot be truly killed.
Dementors can suck the soul out of a person.
The Dementor's Kiss is the act of a Dementor sucking out a person's soul and is considered by some to be a fate worse than death.
Being near Dementors causes depression and despair, as they feed on human happiness. This makes them particularly cruel guards of Azkaban prison.
Dementors have no loyalty, and will serve whoever provides them the most people to feed on.
The average person would likely never or only under extreme circumstances encounter a Dementor.
There is no alternate prison than Azkaban so anyone who gets sent to prison will encounter Dementors.
The Dementors switched sides during the Second Wizarding War: they cannot be controlled and could decide to turn against wizards at any moment.
In some cases, people are sent to Azkaban before it has been proved that they committed a crime.
Boggarts are shape-shifting creatures that assume the form of whatever most frightens the person who encounters them.
All it takes to get rid of a Boggart is a spell that Harry Potter's year mastered at the age of 13.
This spell is not always easy to perform; Molly Weasley struggled immensely when confronted with the apparent bodies of her family.

A poltergeist is a non-being that does not have a physical form and haunts one specific location at time. They delight in vandalism, malicious mischief, and the general aggravation and embarrassment of living persons.
Most of the awful and undesirable creatures are rare or can easily be avoided; they tend not to live in areas where people live.
There are many non-magical creatures that are dangerous and life-threatening, but we still respect them as essential elements of the natural environment.
The wizarding world has developed various techniques for protecting against and isolating dangerous magical creatures.
While more creatures might be present in the wizarding world, wizards lack the complex Muggle technology that allows Muggles to investigate the biology and history of interesting creatures.

The fact that there are antivenoms to most known poisons, Healing spells and potions to treat most diseases and intensive study in Herbology in schools indicates that there is research done in the wizarding world. It is just conducted in a manner different to that in the Muggle World.
There are a number of interesting magical objects and inventions that people in the wizarding world can use.
A Remembrall is a glass ball that fills with red smoke when the owner has forgotten something.
Remembralls are not actually particularly useful items, as they do not specify what it is that you have forgotten.
Omnioculars are the wizarding equivalent of Muggle binoculars, but with the additional features of being able to magically slow down and replay action.
Time-Turners, which resemble hourglasses on necklaces, allow people the opportunity to travel through time.
The use of a Time-Turner allowed Hermione Granger and Harry Potter to save Buckbeak the Hippogriff and help Sirius Black escape.
Hermione Granger was given a Time-Turner to use at Hogwarts to allow her to take more classes.
All of the Ministry of Magic's Time-Turners were destroyed during a battle in the Department of Mysteries.
If the technology to create and store Time-Turners exists, then it seems likely that the Ministry's supply could easily be restored.
The use of the very limited amount of Time-Turners owned by the Ministry of Magic is restricted by hundreds of laws.

A Time-Turner cannot enable 'long-distance' time travel: investigations into time-magic show that "the longest period that may be relived without the possibility of serious harm to the traveller or to time itself is around five hours".
A Pensieve is a dish that is enchanted to recreate memories so that the owner or others can relive them.
One is able to pass on memories to be viewed in a Pensieve, as Snape does when he is dying and he passes on memories to Harry Potter to explain his history with Lily Potter.
Pensieves allow advanced wizards to examine and sort through thoughts and ideas.
If someone accesses someone else's pensieve, the owner's memories can be viewed without their permission which is a gross invasion of privacy.
This is not that different from accidentally leaving confidential information or possessions in a place where others can view them in the Muggle world.
Pensieves are very rare and powerful magical objects, and as such, it is unlikely that most members of the magical community would ever have the opportunity to use one.
Enchanted coins are fake Galleons which can be used for secret communication.
They were created by Hermione Granger in 1995 to communicate with other members of Dumbledore's Army and to organise secret meetings between them.
Mokeskin pouches are a type of draw-string pouch that can be operated only by the owner.
A Sneakoscope, which looks like a glass spinning top, lights up, spins and whistles if something or someone untrustworthy is nearby.
Revealers and Probity Probes can be used to make invisible ink appear and detect spells of concealment and hidden magical objects respectively.
Without the ability to magically hide things in the first place these items would be irrelevant.
Wizard's Chess is played with the rules, pieces and board identical to Muggle chess. However, the pieces are magically animated, and they violently attack each other when performing a capture.

The Weasley family has a special clock in their home with nine hands, one for every member of the family. Instead of telling the time, the clock reveals the location or status of each family member - whether it be 'Home', 'School', 'At Work' or 'In Mortal Peril'.
The memory charm, Obliviate, can be used to selectively alter a person's memory. This means that people do not have to live with negative memories if they would prefer not to.
Oftentimes negative memories serve no purpose and only cause suffering.
If the casting of the spell goes wrong it can cause serious and irreversible memory loss to those subjected to it.
All memories, positive and negative, make up part of a person's lived experience and should not be erased.
The spell can be used maliciously.
Gilderoy Lockhart was notorious for changing the memories of anyone who could dispute his supposed acts of bravery.
There are many interesting magical traits and skills that wizards and witches can acquire, inherit or learn.

Legilimency is the act of magically navigating through the many layers of a person's mind and correctly interpreting one's findings. It is the wizarding equivalent of what Muggles call 'mind reading'. The most advanced Legilimens can perform Legilimency nonverbally and wandlessly, without the victim's consent.
Occlumency is the act of magically closing one's mind against Legilimency and can prevent a Legilimens from accessing one's thoughts and feelings, or influencing them.

The Muggle world recognizes some rights such as the right to life as unalienable because what they protect is sacrosanct. If minds could be invaded in the Muggle world like they can be through Legilimency, protection of one's mental well being would also be such a right. As such, people's minds should be protected regardless of whether they know Occlumency or not, just as the right to life is protected regardless of your ability to protect yourself against external threats.
The right to life does not demand absolute autonomy for one's mind. One can live without a fully autonomous mind.

This is presuming the definition of the right to life would be the same in the wizarding world as it is in the Muggle world. Seeing that wizards have a way to differentiate between the soul and the physical realm of living, it is not unreasonable to say their definitions of the right to life would also be different to incorporate these differences.

This assumes that the wizarding world has a defined right to life. Since it is possible to contact the dead indirectly in the wizarding world, it is possible that people in that world do not have a strong need for this right as Muggles, who cannot be contacted after death.
Just because the dead can be interacted with to some degree does not mean life ought not be protected to the highest extent in the wizarding world.
Occlumency is not normally taught at Hogwarts and it is difficult to master.
A Metamorphmagus is a witch or wizard with the ability to change their physical appearance at will.
This includes the ability to change one feature of their appearance or entirely take on the appearance of another person.
Metamorphmagi are extremely rare as very few people are born with the skill and it is not possible to learn the skill.

A Seer is a gifted wizard or witch who has the ability to see into the future with their Inner Eye. Seers look into future events through visions and dreams or physical objects like tea dregs, tarot cards, and crystal balls.
Through a great deal of study, it is possible to become an Animagus and to be able to transform into a particular animal.
You cannot choose which animal you can transform into, it is linked to your personality.
The process is extremely arduous and can result in permanent half-human, half-animal mutations if done incorrectly.
A Parselmouth can speak to snakes and other magical serpent-based creatures. This ability is extremely rare and is typically hereditary.
The ability to speak to snakes is not a particularly exciting or useful skill.
Given the history of wizards who have been Parselmouths, this skill is actually a bad thing given the way people view those with it.
The ability to obtain information about the life of a non-human creature could certainly be described as exciting.
The ability to speak to a non-human species breaks all barriers of science and technology seen in the Muggle world.
It is a lot easier to design a private space for oneself without being detected or overheard using magic.
The Fidelius Charm can be used to make a location invisible, intangible, unplottable and soundproof.

Cave inimicum is the incantation of a protective spell that conjures up a shield that keeps the caster hidden from others. Those who are on the other side of the shield will not be able to see them, hear them or, if the spell is well-casted, smell them.
Muffliato is a charm used to fill the ears of any person in the vicinity of the caster with an unidentifiable buzzing sound so as to allow conversing without being overheard.
The Imperturbable Charm is a spell that creates a magical barrier on a target object, such as a door, to protect it from eavesdropping.
The Disillusionment Charm is a spell that is used to conceal the target which takes on the colour and texture of its surroundings.
The magical world opens up possibilities of extending one's life and of experiencing some form of life after death.
Horcruxes are objects in which individuals can hide pieces of their soul with the object of achieving immortality. Voldemort successfully split his soul into eight pieces.
Splitting the soul is warned against in Adalbert Waffling's First Fundamental Law Of Magic.

It is difficult for the part of the soul encased in a Horcrux to regain a physical body after the 'main' part of the soul's death. If it does not regain a physical body it continues to exist only in an incorporeal form.
Creating a Horcrux is a very difficult act of magic, and only very few wizards are capable of doing it.
People who have Horcruxes can still ultimately die if the Horcruxes are destroyed, such as in the case of Voldemort.
If the Horcrux is destroyed and the person does die, they appear to become trapped in limbo.
Creating a Horcrux requires the person to commit murder in order to split the soul.
Splitting the soul is nearly irreversible; the only way to make it whole again is for the wizard to truly feel remorse for the murder committed, the pain of which is so great it could kill them.
Many wizards and witches continue to live to some extent through their portraits and are able to interact with people who are still alive.
Even though Harry Potter was orphaned as a baby, he was able to keep the memories he had with his parents through the moving portraits in the photo album Hagrid gave him.
Hogwarts' past Headmasters and Headmistresses live on in their portraits in the current Headmaster's office.
Headmasters' portraits are painted long before the Headmaster dies, and are kept in a cupboard in the castle so that the Headmaster can teach their portrait to speak and act like them.
Headmasters can share specific knowledge and information with their portrait that can then be passed on generations after their death.
Albus Dumbledore visited his portrait regularly to teach it to talk and behave like him.
Magical portraits such as those at Hogwarts do not provide a full way for people to live on, as they only represent the person as seen by the artist.
The creation of a portrait of a wizard is not comparable to that wizard surviving after death. Rather, it is the creation of a simplistic clone of that wizard.
Portraits are only portrayals of the artist's impression of the subject, not accurate representations of the subject themself, and they lack the memories or knowledge of the subject.

For example, some wizards, like Hogwarts headmasters, have portraits created for them when they are already alive. Clearly, in that case, the portrait is not a continuation of the wizard's consciousness, since both exist at the same time.
The degree to which a portrait can interact with the person looking at them depends on the power they possessed when alive.
Wizards have a much longer life-expectancy than Muggles, reaching 137 years in the mid-1990s.
Elderly wizards appear to enjoy a better quality of life than most elderly Muggles.
Most elderly wizards are capable of living alone without assistance. This is relatively less common in the Muggle world.
Many wizards, such as Albus Dumbledore, continue working well into old age. Elderly Muggles are often required to retire at a certain age.
One wizard reached the age of 755 in the 1990s.
Ghosts exist in in the wizarding world and interact with wizards.
Ghosts remember details from the life of their respective person, so they seem to be continuations of their consciousness.
Ghosts have a very reduced quality of life, as they are unable to experience physical pleasure and they only retain the level of knowledge that they had during their mortal life.
Ghosts are still capable of thinking and interacting with people, which is superior to the nothingness of death.
We cannot know that after death there is nothing, just as we cannot know that being a ghost is superior to what happens to wizards after death.
If the people are aware of their diminished capacity, they might well find this worse than nothingness.
It has been said that only those with unfinished business choose to come back as ghosts, while the wisest witches and wizards are more likely to embrace death.
Albus Dumbledore, one of the greatest of wizards, said "To the well-organized mind, death is but the next great adventure."
This implies that the wizarding world has an afterlife, so death in the wizarding world would be superior to death in the Muggle world after all.
There is no reason to believe that Muggles don't also get to experience this implied afterlife.
Wizards who become ghosts never get to experience or have knowledge of what happens after death.
For some ghosts the choice is regretted as they live in ignorance of what they gave up and with the knowledge of how much lesser a ghost's existence is as compared to a living persons.
Due to the fact that they will never experience what happens after death they will be forever left behind by those passing into the afterlife.
It is never answered what happens after death and so we cannot be sure that ghosts are missing out. What happens after death may possibly be worse than life as a ghost.
The torture of never knowing whether you made the correct choice for the entirety of your never-ending existence makes a ghost's life worse no matter what life after death is.

Even if you choose to pass on, you would never know both sides of the choice. While as a mortal you would have seen and talked to ghosts, you would never have known what it is truly like to have been one. No matter which choice you make you will have to live with a certain amount of uncertainty.
This is still a better situation than that in the Muggle world because at least wizards are offered the choice of continuing on as ghosts whereas Muggles are forced to move on to what is beyond.
The Philosopher's Stone, created by Nicolas Flamel, can be used to create the Elixir of Life which can extend the lifespan of those who drink it indefinitely.
Nicolas and Perenelle Flamel both lived to more than 650 years old, and only died after Nicolas agreed to destroy the stone.
The stone was destroyed in 1991 as Dumbledore and Flamel thought it was necessary to stop it falling into the wrong hands after Voldemort had begun a quest to obtain it.
The stone was not necessarily unique, it could be created again by an alchemist equal to Flamel's skill.
The fact that the stone was highly sought after by a dangerous wizard shows that people will go to extreme measures to get access to life expanding magic, meaning it could cause serious problems.
Fable suggests that if a person were to obtain all three of the Deathly Hallows, they would become the master of death.
The Invisibility Cloak renders whoever is under it completely invisible. The Deathly Hallows fable suggests this would allow a person to hide from death.

Unlike other invisibility cloaks that have been created, which tend to lose their magic over time and become patchy in terms of hiding the wearer, the invisibility cloak that Harry Potter owns and which is believed to be a Deathly Hallow, never loses its powers.
The Cloak does not act as a shield against spells, curses, or hexes aimed at the user. It only hides the wearer from sight.
Harry is affected by the Full Body-Bind Curse while under the invisibility cloak.
The Elder Wand is a very powerful wand which can aid its bearer in their attempt to become Master of Death.
The Elder Wand has a bloody history for its owners who are regularly murdered for it.
The Resurrection Stone temporarily brings back the spirits of the holder's dead loved ones.
The Resurrection Stone does not resurrect actual life but rather echoes of the loved ones' spirits.
Harry Potter dropped the stone in a forest as he did not want it. It is unclear where it is now and whether another such stone has ever been created.
The stone has the Deathly Hallows symbol etched upon it, making it recognisable. It is possible that it will one day be found again.
Given the size of the Forbidden Forest relative to the stone and conditions of general wear and tear likely in the Forest, the probability of the stone ever being found again are next to none.
The spirits are uncomfortable in the land of the living.

Cadmus Peverell used the Stone to attempt to bring back a girl he had loved and was prepared to marry before her untimely death. While he was able to bring back a shade of her, he felt as though a "veil" separated them, and he could tell that she was suffering greatly from being forced back among the world of the living.
It has been suggested that being the true Master of Death does not mean accomplishing immortality, but accepting that death is inevitable.
Only one wizard can possess the Hallows, and the probability of managing to be that one wizard is fantastically low.
It is only according to fable that possession of these items can allow one to avoid death.
That the majority of wizards and witches do not go to great lengths to experience life after death suggests that doing so is difficult, unrewarding, or risky.
Most of the options to extend one's life are extreme, such as in the form of creating Horcruxes. Alternatively, they only give a person a partial life, which may well be a worse option than death.
Expanding life expectancy or living forever may not necessarily be a good thing.
Death is a natural part of the human condition; cheating death is wrong.
People are inspired to make the best of their lives because they know that one day, it will end. Cheating death would take away the primary motivation human beings have to do anything productive.
Population control would be a serious problem if people were to live forever, or even for a significantly longer period than they do now.
Immortality would require either severely limiting people's procreative rights, or dealing with an endlessly expanding population.
Most wizards don't choose to seek immortality so it would be unlikely to affect population size greatly.
Given the relative size of the wizarding community, this is unlikely to have a major impact on population control.
Resource limitations that would be a problem for a normal population are less likely to be a problem for a population of wizards who may be able to cast magic spells to solve the problem.
Life is special because of the people we share it with. With an expanded life expectancy or immortality, you would watch everyone you cared about die.
Love is considered the most powerful branch of magic. To live forever would mean living without one's loved ones.
Unless your means of attaining immortality are arbitrarily restricted to yourself, living forever would mean having your loved ones with you forever.

Even if your means of attaining immortality are arbitrarily limited to yourself, to live forever would mean the memory of your loved ones lives on forever with you, rather than being gone from the world.
Being immortal and having the painful memory of one's loved ones forever is a worse outcome than eventually dying, thus having the painful memories only for some time.
Most wizards' loved ones are also wizards so also have expanded life expectancy and the possibility of immortality.
This is increasingly untrue as the number of half-bloods and Muggle-borns grows.
As the example of Hermione wiping her parents' memories with hardly a second thought shows, half-bloods and muggle-borns do not appear to rate their muggle relations as "loved ones".
Life has meaning because of its brevity. If people lived forever, that meaning would be lost.
Longer life expectancies would give people the opportunity to pursue longer-term projects, and discourage short-term hedonism.
A person could spend an infinite amount of time pursuing their dreams or doing what they love if they had the opportunity to live forever.

A lot of people are not able to pursue their fields of interests due to financial or familial pressures while growing up. An infinite time to pursue interests would give people the time to fulfill those obligations before moving on to something that truly makes them happy.

Many people realize after years of working in a particular field that they are better equipped to work in, or are more passionate about, another field. Living longer would allow easier transitions to other fields of work and lead to greater happiness among working individuals.
Many people have more than one dream for a career or life they may lead. Having this time would allow them to live out many different career and life paths that may give them great utility.

The wizarding world offers a choice to extend one's life. People for whom a short lifespan makes life meaningful can choose not to extend their life, while people who do desire longer lifespans can make the opposite choice.
Choosing not to extend one's life will also be a difficult choice to make due to the high quality of life offered in the wizarding world and the connections that are formed with people.
There are a number of magical enhancements wizards can use to breathe under water.
Gillyweed is a magical plant. When it is eaten, one grows gills and webbing between the fingers and toes, allowing one to process oxygen from water and navigate underwater more easily.
A Scuba-Spell is an Underwater Charm used to breathe underwater in lieu of using underwater breathing apparatus.
The Bubble-Head Charm is the most effective spell for breathing underwater allowing one a supply of oxygen.
Muggles can also use scuba equipment or submarines to explore underwater and these technologies are safer than the wizarding methods.
The Muggle world has many forms of entertainment which the wizarding world lacks.
The Muggle world has a large diversity of sports.
The Muggle world has films, TV shows, the internet, and computer games.
Many computer games and entertainment media allow Muggles to watch or emulate fictional magic. The ability to perform real magic would be far more exciting.
It is not impossible in the wizarding world to use muggle entertainment.
Close relationships are what keep people happy throughout their lives. Pursuing interesting possibilities might be fun for a while but it is unlikely to actually improve your life in the long term.
People born into the wizarding world are constantly exposed to magic. This means that they don't find magic particularly exciting or enriching.

Muggles are surrounded by existing technology but are still excited to experience new technology. Given the extent to which magic exists, there will likely always be an element of it that an individual wizard has not experienced before.
Given that magic seems to evolve at a slow rate, it seems likely that this interest would rapidly disappear.
Research on the "hedonic treadmill" indicates that even large changes in wealth or possessions do not affect long-term happiness. The same is probably true for access to interesting magical tricks.

People in the wizarding world have the choice to pursue relationships in the Muggle world but Muggles don't have the analogous privilege because they aren't aware of the magical world's existence. This makes living in the wizarding world preferable as it increases the number of available options.

In general, close relationships with Muggles are rare and the magical community mostly associates with its own members whether because of stigma or the complications of keeping magic a secret. Historically, in countries such as the US, the Muggle and magical communities were even strictly segregated.
Pure-bloods who marry non-pure-bloods are often disowned by their families.
A member of the family was blasted off the Black Family tree for marrying a Weasley - a family renowned for being blood traitors.
Merope Gaunt married Tom Riddle Sr. and was disowned.
Andromeda Tonks was disowned by the Black family for marrying Ted Tonks.
The presence of 'half-blood' as an epithet suggests that marrying Muggles is highly frowned upon and seems extremely rare within the wizarding world.

As per terminology, any wizard who is not either pure-blood or Muggle-born is considered a half-blood, even if they have two wizard parents. Since they need not have exactly half-Muggle/half-wizard heritage, being a half-blood is probably the most common phenomenon in the Wizarding World in terms of heritage.
There were only 28 pure-blood families in 1930s Britain (and likely far fewer today) suggesting that marrying a Muggle is actually fairly common.

Many well-known and popular wizards and witches, like Gilderoy Lockhart, Tom Marvolo Riddle (Lord Voldemort), Severus Snape, Dolores Umbridge, Albus Dumbledore and Harry Potter, had a Muggle-born parent.

While wizards have the ability to pursue these interesting possibilities, they are also able to seek close relationships as those in the Muggle world have. Many develop long term friendships and relationships.
It is not necessary for wizards to develop relationships with Muggles to have the fulfilment, as there are enough people in the wizarding community for them to still develop meaningful relationships.
The Muggle world is also full of endless quantities of knowledge, hobbies, interests, and skills.
Wizards also have the possibility of exploring Muggle knowledge, hobbies, interests and skills if they so choose.
Muggle Studies is an elective subject students can take from Third Year through to Seventh Year.
Muggle Studies is taught by a wizard meaning the information is unlikely to be a fully accurate representation of the Muggle world.
Prejudice against the Muggle world would stop many wizards from taking an interest in such Muggle things.
Magic can also be used for evil purposes by those with bad intentions.
Dark wizards like Grindelwald, Voldemort, and the Death Eaters use magic to create pain, terror and death.

Simple items can be transformed into dangerous ones which are intended to cause harm. For example, the black quill that Professor Umbridge made Harry Potter use during detentions used his blood as ink and carved anything he wrote with the quill into his hand.

Simple and useful items being used to cause harm is not a practice exclusive to the wizarding world. There are many useful things that can be used for good and for evil in the Muggle world. For example, a knife can be used for cooking but also for stabbing and maiming.
There is a great capacity to harm others using the Unforgivable Curses.
The Imperius Curse can cause the victim to perform the unquestioned bidding of the caster.
The ability to torture an individual and destroy their mental capacity is available through the Cruciatus Curse.
Advanced torture techniques are available in the Muggle world as well and have been in use for centuries.
While this is true, this torture is easier in the wizarding world.
All that is required for torture in the wizarding world is a wand, whereas advanced torture techniques in the Muggle world often require special implements and facilities.
With a simple Avada Kedavra spell, anyone can be murdered in an instant.
There is no defense to the Avada Kedavra spell other than avoiding it.
Wands are easy to conceal and use, so it is harder to predict and defend against a Killing Curse than it is to defend against Muggle weapons.
There are plenty of possibilities in the Muggle world to murder people in an instant.
Most Muggle ways of intentionally killing someone are not instantaneous.

The methods of murder in the Muggle world that are not instantaneous are often incredibly painful and the victim goes through a tremendous amount of suffering. Asphyxiation, poisoning, forced drowning or bludgeoning are some examples of this.
