Suffering an instantaneous and painless death from the killing curse would be preferable to vast number of these methods.
Items can be cursed to harm those who touch them, such as the opal necklace which was used to curse Katie Bell.

The misuse of technology by some to harm others is not a phenomenon exclusive to the magical world. History shows people like Pol Pot and Hitler and the Nazis who caused great amounts of harm to the Muggle world by abusing their power.
Magic creates great potential for deception and manipulation.
Animagi are able to masquerade as animals unbeknown to other wizards.

The Ministry registers Animagi but there were at least four Animagi (James Potter, Peter Pettigrew, Sirius Black and Rita Skeeter) that were never registered or caught by the Ministry. Since the official list of Animagi is so small, there might be many more illegal Animagi living within the wizarding world.

Felix Felicis, also called "Liquid Luck", is a magical potion that makes the drinker lucky for a period of time, during which everything they attempt will be successful, irrespective of their skill level or preparedness for that venture.
It is a banned substance in all organised competitions as it is considered a form of cheating.
It is incredibly difficult to make and cannot be accessed by most wizards.
Memories of individuals can be deleted or false memories can be implanted via charms without the target realizing it.
The Ministry of Magic uses Obliviators to remove memories of Muggles that witness something related to the wizarding world.
Love potions can be used to create affectionate or even obsessive feelings that override rational thought. This makes them the ultimate substance for date rape.
Invisibility cloaks and disillusionment charms can help people to hide, escape, eavesdrop and stalk.
Invisibility cloaks and disillusionment charms also have legitimate and beneficial uses.
Many of those possibillities seem barbaric or backwards by our society standards, such as the free trade of rape drugs (love potions) that lead to the birth of a terrorist.
The wizarding world is authoritarian, oppressive, and intrusive.
There is a decided lack of privacy in the wizarding world.
The Marauder's Map shows every inch of the Hogwarts grounds and where everyone is every minute of every day.
The Marauder's Map was created illegally and would be immediately confiscated by someone in a position of authority.
If the Marauder's Map could be created in secret and kept hidden by teenagers, there is no doubt that something similar could be created by others.

The government keeps records of all citizens. In Professor McGonagall's office, a magic quill writes down the name of every wizard and witch when they are born. Because the school answers to the Ministry of Magic, the government has a record of every member of the population.
Most governments keep records of all citizens, including birth certificates and death certificates.
The Trace Charm allows the Ministry to track the activity and location of all underage wizards with great accuracy.
The Trace is only put on underage wizards to uphold the International Statute of Secrecy, to prevent exposure to Muggles.
It is impossible to subject adults beyond the age of 17 to the Trace Charm.
People can Apparate unexpectedly into private rooms and spaces.
Privacy in the Muggle world is decreasing rapidly due to the advent of the Internet. Since the wizarding world lacks technology, it may soon be more private than the Muggle world.
Internet surveillance by the government is common in many countries.
On the Internet, everyone's consumption patterns are minutely tracked.

The high value placed on privacy by Muggles is a social construct that developed as a result of social evolution. The magical community is mostly aware of these intrusive government policies and that they are not displeased by these actions; this attitude points to a general social outlook that does not value privacy to the extent that the Muggle community does. As such, the acts of the government cannot be seen as oppressive.
In Great Britain, the Ministry of Magic has authoritarian tendencies.
Heads of Ministry Departments (which appear to be equivalent to Muggle government Ministers) are not elected representatives of the people.
This is also the case in the US Muggle system which would generally be seen as very democratic.
There are few checks or balances on the power of the Ministry of Magic or the Minister for Magic, and no one within the ministry disputes official policy.
There is no opposition party, like exists in almost all Muggle governments, to question laws passed by the government and hold the government accountable for promises made to the community.
The Ministry is very susceptible to corruption.
Voldemort managed to take control of the Ministry without anyone knowing, by putting Pius Thicknesse under the Imperius Curse when he was Minister for Magic.
The awarding of the Order of Merlin is not always based on merit. Sometimes it is due to the recipient's position within the Ministry or their wealth.
The Ministry of Magic considered removing Albus Dumbledore's Order of Merlin as part of a campaign to discredit him because he disagreed with Cornelius Fudge.
Arcturus Black, Sirius Black's grandfather, was widely believed to have bought his Order of Merlin by loaning the Ministry a large amount of gold.
Cornelius Fudge awarded himself the Order of Merlin, First Class, for a career few considered distinguished.
Many honorifics in the Muggle world are subject to the same problem. This is not unique to the wizarding world.
The Ministry of Magic has proven to be incompetent many times.

The Ministry of Magic led by Cornelius Fudge systematically denied and made no effort to verify Voldemort's return even though there were credible witnesses like Harry Potter and Albus Dumbledore attesting to the contrary.
When Voldemort returns, kills the Minister for Magic and replaces him with Pius Thicknesse, the entire government follows Thicknesse's orders, even though the orders are violent, racist and insane.
Thicknesse, at Voldemort's direction, installed a new regime at the Ministry that was more in line with Death Eater ideology.
Thicknesse appointed known Death Eaters with criminal records to important offices.
Corban Yaxley was appointed head of the Department of Magical Law Enforcement.
Then Death Eater, Severus Snape, was appointed Headmaster of Hogwarts.
Death Eaters Travers and Selwyn, were appointed to other powerful positions within the Ministry Department of Magical Law Enforcement.
Public dissent was unjustly cracked down upon under Thicknesse's regime.
Xenophilius Lovegood's daughter, Luna, was kidnapped in order to stop his telling the truth to the public and encouraging support of Harry Potter in his magazine, The Quibbler.
Xenophilius was later arrested and imprisoned without trial.
Known Order of the Phoenix members or those with sympathies for Muggles, such as Arthur Weasley, were put under Ministry surveillance.
Pius Thicknesse enacted policies that perpetuated hatred against all wizards of Muggle ancestry and the Muggle community itself.

Using falsified research done in the Department of Mysteries, the Ministry claimed that Muggle-borns "stole" their magic from "real" witches and wizards. As a result, the Muggle-born Registration Commission was set up to persecute and imprison Muggle-borns.
The Snatchers, an organisation of Dark wizards who acted as bounty hunters, was formed to round up any Muggle-borns or blood traitors on the run.
The period of stringent government policy during the Second Wizarding War is understood to be an aberration rather than the norm.

Thicknesse had a statue depicting a witch and wizard on top of a throne made from the bodies of crude-looking Muggles, inscribed with the motto "Magic is Might" set up in the Ministry Atrium, replacing the earlier Fountain of Magical Brethren.
Under Thicknesse, Hogwarts school policy was changed to better align with Dark ideology.
Death Eaters Amycus and Alecto Carrow were appointed to teach the Dark Arts and prejudiced depictions of Muggles.
Unlike previously, Hogwarts attendance became compulsory and Muggle-borns were rusticated following a blood purity check.
The problems that are seen in the Thicknesse Ministry have been seen countless times in dictatorial regimes throughout human history. They are a problem of dictatorships and not magic.
The Ministry of Magic enables discrimination rather than protecting minorities.
Throughout history, Ministry of Magic policies regarding werewolves have been ineffective in curbing the spread of lycanthropy or challenging the stigma associated with being a werewolf.
Those identified as werewolves, like Remus Lupin, face prejudice and often have a hard time keeping a job.
Muggles who suffer from chronic Muggle illnesses, like HIV/AIDS, face similar discrimination in the Muggle world.
The Ministry of Magic has increasingly restricted the land on which Centaurs can live.
The Ministry bans non-human magical creatures from carrying wands.
Some magical creatures also refuse to share their magical secrets with witches and wizards: for example, goblin-made silver.
Non-human creatures have their own brands of magic and do not need wands to perform magic.
House elves are able to use their magic and Apparate even in places equipped with anti-Apparition charms.

The house-elves at Hogwarts can Apparate within its walls, Kreacher was able to escape from the lake where Voldemort hid his Horcrux and Dobby was able to Apparate within and out of Malfoy Manor when it was used to house prisoners.
Some human-like creatures like trolls and giants are not intellectually developed enough to use wands responsibly.
The Ministry permits house-elves to be enslaved for generations at a time.
House-elves have no rights of their own and are subjected to terrible living conditions. For example, Kreacher had to sleep in a cupboard under a boiler while serving the Black family.
The contract between house-elves and masters strip the elves of all agency. Elves are obligated to do their master's bidding, and are forced to punish themselves if they disobey commands.
Dobby was forced to serve the Malfoy family despite being treated brutally.
Kreacher was forced to do Sirius Black's bidding even though he despised Sirius.
Kreacher managed to bypass Sirius' orders by interpreting his orders, which lead to Sirius's death.

The Ministry allows institutional enslavement of elves. Hogwarts school has a team of house-elves who are responsible for cooking, cleaning and maintaining the castle without ever being heard or seen.
House-elves seem to respect the culture of enslavement.
House-elves prefer to work in hiding, and consider it mark of professionalism that they do all the work but their existence is never noticed.
House-elves feel insulted if their master attempts to pay them, give them pensions, or reward their service with anything except gratitude.

When Hermione Granger began hiding clothes in Gryffindor Tower in an attempt to free the house-elves of Hogwarts, the house-elves felt insulted, and everyone except Dobby refused to clean the Gryffindor common room in protest.
House-elves suffer from the lack of education organised by the Ministry of Magic in order to brainwash them and make them accept their position in the magical society.

The Society for the Promotion of Elfish Welfare (S.P.E.W.) was an organisation founded in 1994 by Hermione Granger in response to what she saw as gross injustice in the treatment of house-elves at the 1994 Quidditch World Cup. Also, Hermione went on to work for the Department for the Regulation and Control of Magical Creatures, where she continued to work for the rights of magical creatures. She may have re-founded SPEW as a semi-department and part of her Department.
Even though their brand of magic is powerful and wandless, they never harm their masters, despite being subjected to terrible living and working conditions.
The magical contract between house-elves and their masters prevents them from harming their masters.

Kreacher hated his master Sirius Black and always looked for loopholes in Sirius' commands to spite him. But Kreacher couldn't explicitly harm Sirius despite his feelings because the magical contract prevented him from harming his master.

House-elves find ways to bypass their enslavement in order to harm their masters. For instance, Kreacher manages to lead his master Sirius Black to death; Dobby's attempt at saving Harry's life causes at the same time harm to his master Lucius. House-elves have free will and are not that protective towards their masters.
The house-elves’ resistance to their freedom is an indication of the depth of their bondage rather than their own desire.

W. E. B. DuBois in his work The Souls of Black Folk observed this phenomenon that happens in the case of groups that suffer extended periods of prejudice. Over time, the self-image of these groups aligns with the image of them held by those that keep them in bondage which plays a part in maintaining their state.

The way house-elves feel about their lives can be likened to the most extreme case of Stockholm Syndrome. They have been denied rights and agency for so long that they now feel it their duty to remain enslaved.

The enslavement of house-elves is still morally wrong. They are rational, autonomous beings and the wizarding community owes to them every moral protection that they would owe to other human beings since they have free will and the ability to reason.
Kreacher shows free will in his attempts to resist Sirius’s efforts to get rid of his mother’s artifacts.
Dobby delivers a warning to Harry against the wishes of his master, knowing that doing so will be problematic for him.
Dobby understood the rules around enslavement, but made it very clear to Harry Potter that he was mistreated and unhappy with the Malfoys.
The Ministry of Magic is not representative of the whole of the Wizarding community.
The wizarding world takes International Statute of Secrecy very seriously and yet the department that deals with Muggles, Misuse of Muggle Artefacts Office, is underfunded and has only two people.
Many wizards were able to escape and hide from the Ministry easily.
Sirius Black was able to escape from Ministry officials and remain in hiding successfully.
Voldemort was able to hide for years from the Ministry.
After his fall to the baby Harry Potter, Voldemort was able to evade the Ministry of Magic effectively because the Ministry was not aware of his Horcruxes and he was presumed dead.
It was Voldemort's followers inside the Ministry, rather than institutional incompetence, that allowed him to evade capture.
The Ministry tried to maintain a facade of stability after Voldemort's rise after the Triwizard Tournament. Voldemort took advantage of this attitude to evade capture.
The fact that the Ministry was able to be corrupted is a sign of its incompetence in itself.
Dumbledore was able to escape from his office at Hogwarts after knocking out Ministry wizards.
One of the Ministry wizards who was trying to apprehend Dumbledore was Kingsley Shacklebolt, one of Dumbledore's closest allies.
The fact that one of the world's most powerful wizards cannot be stopped by a few lower ones is not necessarily testament to the Ministry's incompetence but rather Dumbledore's strength.
There have been at least five occasions in which prisoners have escaped from Azkaban despite it being considered inescapable.
Ministers for Magic can be ousted by votes of no confidence.
Cornelius Fudge was removed from his position as Minister for Magic through a vote of no confidence.
This is used in the most extreme circumstances and is usually not used as a threat to keep a check on the Minister's abuse of power.
Political parties do not appear to exist in the wizarding world.
While political parties don't exist, political lobbying groups, like SPEW, aim to ensure the interests of various groups are heard.
The Ministry of Magic controls everything, from banks to schools to law enforcement to journalism.

There is only one wizarding newspaper in England - the Daily Prophet - and it reports on gossip in addition to news. It is also susceptible to pressure from the Minister for Magic to print or not to print information.

Under pressure from the Ministry, The Daily Prophet tries its best to ruin Harry Potter and Albus Dumbledore's reputations when they try to warn the wizarding world about the second coming of Voldemort.
Cornelius Fudge prevents the Daily Prophet from printing news about Voldemort's return.
One newspaper means that different political views are not represented in the wizarding world and there is no proper scrutiny of government.
There are some smaller alternative newspapers such as The Quibbler.
When the Daily Prophet refuses to print certain information, the popularity of these smaller newspapers grows. If the Daily Prophet does not do its job effectively, people will go elsewhere.
Most lucrative careers in the wizarding world are with the government - auror, journalist, professor, bureaucrat - and are awarded to those with favorable political affiliations.
Dolores Umbridge receives repeated appointments (Defence Against the Dark Arts teacher, Hogwarts High Inquisitor) not because of her qualifications, but because of her loyalty to Fudge.
Journalists in the wizarding world do not work for the government; the Daily Prophet and other publications are independent.

The Daily Prophet has strong ties with the Ministry of Magic, and has been used during Ministry campaigns to do things such as discredit Dumbledore and Harry Potter when they claimed Voldemort had returned.

The banks of the wizarding world are depicted as being controlled by the Goblins who are skilled at using magical and biological capabilities to deter outsider control of the wizarding banking system.
The institution of Hogwarts successfully resisted numerous attempts by the Ministry of Magic to impose new educational guidelines, particularly those attempted by Dolores Umbridge.
Even while Umbridge was in full control of the school, teachers subtly assisted in pranks against her and students taught themselves.

Umbridge successfully implemented many of her reforms and even briefly rose to the position of Headmistress. Were it not for the reappearance of Voldemort at the Ministry, these would have likely stayed in place.
The wizarding world does not separate its executive or legislative from its judicial branch.
The Wizengamot is wizarding Britain's high court of law and parliament. Its hearings are conducted in the Ministry of Magic itself - the legislative and executive body of Britain's wizarding world.
The Minister for Magic chairs the Wizengamot to pass Wizarding Laws, or to hear important trials.
The Wizengamot was presided over by the Minister for Magic - the head of the executive branch of government - in the 1995 trial of Harry Potter.
The final verdict is decided by the Wizengamot through a majority vote.
The separation of powers is necessary to prevent abuse of power by those in government.

Due to the existence of magical methods of recalling memories and verifying the truthfulness of claims, the judicial system of the wizarding world does not need judicial independence in order to operate effectively.
This might be the case in theory but in practice these methods are not actually used to determine innocence.
The wizarding justice system lacks due process.
Newt Scamander and Tina Goldstein are sentenced to death without a trial, and without even being accused of any particularly grievous crimes.
In Britain, there are no provisions to appeal decisions to higher courts after the Wizengamot has come to a decision.

Hagrid was ostracised and suspended from Hogwarts, then sent to Azkaban when Ginny Weasley was manipulated into opening the Chamber of Secrets, just because he was suspected of opening it the first time.
Despite the fact that he was innocent, Sirius Black was the victim of numerous miscarriages of justice.
Barty Crouch Senior sentenced Sirius Black to life imprisonment in Azkaban without a trial. Sirius Black was later proved to be innocent.
Sirius Black's punishment was switched from life in Azkaban to being subjected to the Dementor's Kiss after he escaped. The punishment does not seem to fit the crime.
No wizarding lawyers seem to exist, and the practice of having a spokesperson on behalf of a defendant appears to be rare.
Rufus Scrimgeour asks Hermione if she is planning to follow a career in magical law suggesting that this career pathway does exist.
Dumbledore acts as 'witness for the defence' in Harry's trial in front of the Wizengamot, a role which seems to be more like that of defence counsel.
Dumbledore's actions on behalf of Harry are an exceptional circumstance. The concept of legal representation through lawyers is still informal and rare in the wizarding world.
Newt Scamander and his companions are thrown directly into prison cells before they have a chance to plead their case to the Magical Congress of the United States of America.
The Muggle justice system is more economically divisive than the wizarding equivalent.

In the Muggle system, the quality of representation a defendant gets depends on one's ability to pay for a good lawyer. Poor Muggles get incarcerated at higher rates and take worse plea deals because they cannot afford a good lawyer. The Wizengamot, by not allowing lawyers, makes sure that all who come before it have equal opportunity to defend themselves.
A study that has found that unattractive Muggle defendants who cannot afford to dress well to court tend to get hit with longer, harsher sentences -- on average 22 months longer in prison.
There is no evidence to suggest that jurors in the Wizengamot are immune to letting their personal biases dictate whether a defendant is innocent or guilty.
The Muggle world also has cases where innocent people spend a great deal of time in prison, and even innocent people can be sentenced to the death penalty.
These Muggles still normally receive a fair trial beforehand to give them as much chance to prove their innocence as possible.
The Muggle justice system is often regarded as racist, failing to follow due process and giving harsher punishments to people of colour.
While there are no term limits, the Minister for Magic is obliged to hold elections at least every seven years.
Seven years is a very long term, and makes democratic accountability weak.
There is no real public resentment against the actions of the Ministry.

This might be due to an uneducated wizarding public: political education seems to play no role whatsoever in schools and wizards seem to be largely ignorant of political systems other than their own (like those of Muggles).
The Ministers for Magic are held accountable by the wizarding populace. Throughout history, Ministers who have pursued unpopular agendas have been ousted.
The authoritarian methods of the Ministry are legitimized by its ongoing success: for the most part, it has kept Muggles safe from wizards and the other way around.
The Ministry did not prevent three Wizarding Wars which killed many wizards and Muggles.
Wizarding culture is cruel and nefarious as it does not respect the mind and soul of the individual as sacrosanct.
The justice system in the wizarding world is worse than that of the Muggle world.
The wizarding justice system supports punishments that the Muggle world would easily classify as 'cruel and unusual'.
As head of Wizengamot, Barty Crouch Sr fought violence with violence, and authorized the use of the Unforgivable Curses against suspects.
A lot of Muggle governments have suspended due process in times of emergency. This is not unique to the wizarding world.
The use of Dementors as prison guards is accepted, even though this effectively represents torture: they are meant to cause depression and destroy the souls of their victims.
The Dementors were furthermore used as executioners by administering the Dementor's Kiss. According to some, this fate is worse than death.

Experts in the magical world and proponents of Azkaban as the wizarding prison said that the only reason the Dementors stayed on the isolated island (where they had been created) was because they had souls to feed on. If the wizarding prison were shifted elsewhere and the Dementors were deprived of prisoners, they might abandon the prison and head for the mainland.
The Ministry of Magic stopped the use of Dementors after the Second Wizarding War as they had previously proven not trustworthy and supported Lord Voldemort.
The fact that the wizarding world ceased to use Dementors for pragmatic, rather than ethical, reasons indicates that the morality of the wizarding world is still bankrupt.

There are tools that could be used to determine innocence or guilt - the Priori Incantatem incantation, legilimency, or Veritaserum -  but they are rarely used, and instead innocent people are convicted of crimes they did not commit.
Veritaserum would constitute a severe violation of defendants' rights and due process. No-one should be forced to testify against him or herself.
The right against self-incrimination is part of the US Constitution.

The giving of rights to citizens varies greatly from state to state and comes from years of discussion on what constitutes rights and how they are exercised. It is possible that the right against self-incrimination is one not afforded to individuals in the wizarding community.
Even if it is not currently, the right against self-incrimination ought to be part of wizarding society, and forcing people to testify against themselves is a violation of their rights.

This is an argument made from a Muggle perspective on what a rights framework ought to be. There is no 'best' or most 'correct' rights framework. It varies on a case by case basis, and the framework of rights established by wizards cannot be attacked as insufficient through a Muggle lens.
The privilege against self-incrimination is a fundamental common law right protected in the UK.
Veritaserum could be used as a voluntary opt-in for people to prove their innocence.
This would still skew the justice system in an unfair way: if defendants were allowed to use Veritaserum to prove their innocence, any defendant who chose not to would be presumed guilty.

The practice of sending people to Azkaban without a trial was most common during the First Wizarding War and during the attacks on students at Hogwarts when the Ministry was under duress and strapped for resources.

Due process is sometimes also restricted in the Muggle world in times of declared National Emergencies. The conditions under which due process was suspended by the Ministry of Magic is analogous to such situations.
Strained resources or duress are never an excuse for egregiously violating due process; even militaries in warzones have properly administrated trials.

The use of magical means of evidence gathering like Priori Incantatum or the administration of Veritaserum is quick and easy. It is irresponsible and morally reprehensible on the part of the Ministry to prosecute innocent people just to appear like it is fulfilling its responsibility to the public.
The use of Priori Incantatum may be able to identify the spells cast from a wand but cannot identify the wizard who cast them. As such, it cannot prove guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.
The fact that there is no alternate prison means that everyone, no matter the severity of their crime, is sent to Azkaban, an isolated island with Dementors.

After the International Statute of Secrecy had been imposed, Ministry of Magic officials felt that the small wizarding prisons that existed throughout the country posed a security risk, because escape attempts often included noise and lights. They saw Azkaban as a proper prison on a remote island, and one that would help keep the wizarding world secret.

The justice system in the wizarding world is perhaps worse than the British justice system, but the Muggle world is much larger than Britain and Ireland. There is no one type of Muggle justice system, and many Muggle countries have far worse systems in place.
The wizarding world has confirmed, empirical evidence for the existence of souls and yet the general public accepts the destruction of the soul as a form of punishment.
Unless one is proposing the genocide of Dementors, one must accept that some souls will be destroyed in order for Dementors to be able to consume what appears to be their only food.

Former Minister for Magic Eldritch Diggory formed a committee to find alternative solutions to Dementors in Azkaban. This was met with strong opposition because people feared a mainland invasion by the dark creatures if they were deprived of their only food source.

Genocide requires a hostile intention. In this case, the death of Dementors would merely be the result of protecting human beings from unacceptable suffering. This harm could, thus, be inflicted on Dementors without any hostile intention at all.
Regardless of the intent, if we deny food for Dementors in the knowledge that it will cause their extinction then this is still wrong.
The magical world strives to find an appropriate balance by only giving to the Dementors those who are most deserving of this punishment.
Sirius Black was almost given to the Dementors without trial.
That wizards and witches buy in to wizarding society rather than abandoning the state or living amongst Muggles suggests that it is either not that bad, or that the upsides are worth it.
Groups the Ministry of Magic actively discriminates against, including goblins, elves, and centaurs, have no practical options other than being subject to this system.
This is a not a reasonable choice that wizards could ever take.

Given the amount of stigma associated with being a Muggle, and all the social connections that they develop in growing up in the wizarding world, it seems unlikely that a wizard could ever actively make the choice to renounce their own community and join the Muggles.
Most wizards are unfamiliar with the Muggle world, and would have no idea how to effectively integrate into it once they are old enough to make the choice.

Despite the inadequacies of the wizarding world's governing institutions, individuals capable of magic do not appear to need wizarding government services in order to survive and provide for their families.
The capacity for harm is greater when magic is involved.
The scale of harm permitted by magic is seemingly infinite, while the possible positive effects have an upper bound - the dead cannot be revived, and souls cannot be returned.
One creative dark wizard, or even a curious but ill-advised non-dark wizard, could end the world with very little effort.
Transfiguring matter into dark matter could create an explosion large enough to render the earth uninhabitable. There would be no defense against this kind of threat.
A significant number of wizards throughout wizarding history have practised the Dark Arts.
Herpo the Foul invented many vile curses, was the first wizard to hatch a Basilisk and invented Horcruxes.
Salazar Slytherin built a secret chamber underneath Hogwarts to house a Basilisk with the intention of the beast one day being unleashed on Muggle-Born students.
Ekrizdis magically lured, tortured and killed Muggles.
Defense is also made easier through magic.
The wizarding world lacks many of the deadly weapons present in the Muggle world.
The institutions of the wizarding world do not appear to stockpile weapons to use against one another.
The wizarding world does not need deadly weapons to cause significant harm. Various curses can cause the same or even higher level of harm as any Muggle weapon.
Weapons of mass destruction such as nuclear, chemical and biological weapons are far worse than any military technology available in the wizarding world.
Weapons of mass destruction are also possible to use for non-muggles. If Voldemort wanted to use nuclear weapons, he could easily steal them.
Although there are no statistics about the murder rate in the wizarding world, it seems to have a lower murder rate than most of the Muggle world.
The wizarding world is not a separate world. There is nothing stopping people in the wizarding world from using Muggle weapons.
There is no entrenched culture of militarism in the magical world.
There is no evidence of international wars or military tensions in the wizarding world like those that exist in the Muggle world.
There are other possible explanations for the lack of international warfare in the wizarding community. It does not necessarily mean they are less militaristic.
A full scale war between wizarding nations would also break the International Statute of Secrecy, which is treated as sacrosanct by the global magical community.
Wars are usually fought out of resource scarcity or for territorial advancement, both of which are unlikely in the wizarding world.
Wizarding communities do not have clearly defined territory because they are so intertwined with the Muggle world.
Wizards have no incentive to engage in international wars for resources, since magic prevents resource scarcity.
Because wizarding communities are isolated from each other, there is not much opportunity for international interaction and warfare.
The Ministry of Magic does not have a standing army.
The Auror Department is essentially a standing army, given that the only weaponisation wizards need to wage war is their wands and Aurors are highly trained in magical combat.
Given the small size of the Auror department, it seems disingenuous to characterise them as a standing army; instead they act more as a police force.
Both Voldemort and Gellert Grindelwald had armies of followers to aid them in their respective missions.
Voldemort's army consisted of not only Dark Wizards called Death Eaters but also various other creatures like giants, Dementors, Acromantulas and werewolves.

The existence of these "armies" does not necessarily mean that there is wide-spread militarism in the magical world. Rather, Voldemort and Grindelwald resemble revolutionary leaders with large and violent followings.
The Order of the Phoenix was an army that actively fought against the Death Eaters.
Magic also has the capacity to do good as it can be a significant time and effort saver, allowing wizards to contribute positively to society in easy ways with little difficulty.
For many Muggles, limited time stops them from being able to contribute to charities etc. Things that occupy a lot of time, such as housework, can be completed much more quickly with magic.
This assumes that they would use this additional time for charitable causes. It is just as plausible they would fill it with other things they wanted to do.
The average wizard significantly outlives the average Muggle. This also gives them more time to devote to worthwhile causes.
Automation and technological developments mean that Muggles can achieve the sorts of everyday efficiency gains that magic brings.
The wizarding world displays immense moral negligence by refusing to help solve the problems of the Muggle world.
Wizards could solve almost all non-war humanitarian crises.
Magic could help mitigate and manage the effects of natural disasters.
The Aqua Eructo charm creates fresh water out of nothing, and could thus be used to alleviate droughts.
The Reductor Curse or Shrinking Charm could be used to easily get rid of the debris caused by natural disasters, which otherwise takes months to get rid of by Muggle means.
The Vanishing Spell could be used to get rid of toxic waste spills that pollute the planet.
Magic could be used to strengthen buildings and homes against the effects of natural disasters. This could save lives and millions in property damage caused by disasters.
Wizards can multiply and enlarge existing food; they thus have the capacity to solve all major famines, but fail to do so.
We already grow enough food to feed ten billion people, yet one billion are hungry. Clearly, the amount of food is not the issue.

Even if we could in principle distribute existing food to feed everyone who is hungry, creating more food is an alternative, easier way of solving starvation that does not require systematically reforming the world economy.

Accepting the existence and use of magic would require systematically reforming the way in which all Muggles see and interact with the world, which is even more challenging than reforming economic policy.
Wizards could multiply the supply of vaccines, mosquito nets, and other essential items that people living in poverty in low-income countries need.
There would still be a great deal of inequality that magic alone cannot solve. Exceptions to Gamp's Law of Elemental Transfiguration include food and money, which cannot be created out of thin air.
Food cannot be created out of thin air, but already existing food can be multiplied or magically transported from one place to another.
Wizards can increase the food they have through the Engorgement Charm. Hagrid does this with vegetables on the Hogwarts grounds.
Spells could be used quickly to wash, fold and provide blankets and other needed items to homeless people, charities, and towns or states following disasters.
Magic could compensate for the lack of social workers, funding or infrastructure that is endemic to a lot of Muggle social service systems.
Revealing magic to Muggle scientists could result in huge technological advancements that could massively increase the prosperity of the Muggle world.

Magic does not obey the scientific laws that govern the Muggle world. It is therefore unlikely that Muggle scientists would ever be able to understand or implement magic in a way that solves Muggle problems.
Wizards could prevent the cruelties of animal farming from being necessary by multiplying existing quantities of meat.

It is unknown as to whether or not the Gemino Curse can duplicate living or sentient beings. Additionally, only the original caster could stop the multiplication of the object, which could get tricky.Harry Potter Wiki
By that logic, there is a lot that Muggles could do to reduce suffering of animals in the wild as well.
Magic could offer a source of clean, renewable energy.
Magic can produce heat and fire without using electricity or energy.

It is possible that magic would allow us to access this renewable energy at a fraction of the current cost, making it an appealing alternative and allowing for a great reduction in carbon emissions which contribute to climate change.
Wizards can multiply the supply of existing sources of energy, like solar panels or batteries.
Cars can be enchanted so they could run without fuel like how Arthur Weasley and Sirius Black enchanted their car and motorbikes respectively to fly.
Magic can provide light without using electricity or energy.
Wizards could prevent anyone from ever being wrongfully imprisoned by supplying Muggle justice systems with Veritaserum.

The victim states what only they believe to be true, so the victim's sanity and perception of reality also factors in during interrogations. Therefore, while the drinker's answers are sincere, they are not necessarily true.
The wizarding world's failure to aid the Muggle world shows a systematic callousness and refusal to care about the plight of vulnerable people. This makes it an undesirable place to live.
Wizards have a good reason for not solving the problems of the Muggle world: they see continued secrecy as key to their survival.

Not only would extermination of the wizarding world be a threat to wizards themselves, but it would remove the ability of wizards to help Muggles. So if this fear were accurate, helping Muggles would be self-defeating, so wizards have good reason not to help them.
Historically, witches and wizards were burned at the stake for fear of their powers.

The same was true during the Middle Ages for heretics, Jews, and those who engaged in sodomy. We have come a long way since then. Therefore, it is unlikely that witches and wizards would be treated today as was the case back then.
Muggles are hostile to what they do not understand.
Wizards could alleviate the problems of the Muggle world while remaining in secret.
Wizards could create Muggle companies or NGOs as fronts to distribute magically created food in famines.

Wizarding culture is too different from Muggle culture for them to be able to run a public institution such as an international NGO while at the same time being able to withstand the public scrutiny that comes with it.
If wizards were able to use magic to reverse things such as the effects of climate change, then they could likely do so without being detected by Muggles.
The study of climate change relies on empirical scientific evidence. If climate change began to reverse without any apparent causation it would arouse concern in Muggle scientists.
Given most Muggles currently don't believe in magic, it is unlikely that such concern would lead them to the suspicion of magic being the cause.
The wizarding world would easily survive exposure to, and harm from, the Muggle world.
Wizards can travel instantly, use magic to multiply or transport their possessions, and hide easily. Even if the Muggle world attacked them, they would easily survive.

Even if wizards could individually survive a Muggle attack on the wizarding world by constantly relocating or hiding, it would totally destroy wizarding society and institutions. Fear of this is a sufficient reason to remain in secret.
The domain of the magical community is often not present to Muggles at all.
Platform 9 3/4, Grimmauld Place and Hogwarts are all invisible to Muggles.

It was possible to avoid witch burnings. Witches and wizards could perform a charm to neutralize the flames and then stand within the fires set for them, feeling nothing but “a gentle tickling sensation”.
Wizards' enchantments and protections are designed to withstand magic and magical attacks. It is possible that wizards would have no idea how to defend themselves from Muggle bombs or other weapons.

There is no reason to believe that magical protections that withstand powerful magical attacks would not be able to be adapted, or used in their current form, to withstand Muggle attacks from Muggle weaponry.

Most Muggle weaponry requires causing physical harm which could easily be stopped by a magical barrier. For example, projectiles like bullets or crossbows could be Transfigured into something harmless or levitated away and knife blades could be made to disappear and their wounds easily healed.
Whether or not they have a good reason is irrelevant - the fact of the matter is that continued secrecy makes the wizarding world a paranoid, unpleasant place to live.
If the wizarding world magically solved Muggles' problems for them, then Muggles would become reliant on magical solutions instead of attempting to solve their own problems.
Every human doesn't have every skill possible. We already rely on each other.
Periodically through history wizards have aided the Muggle world when the situation was dire.
During the Muggle First World War, thousands of witches and wizards aided Muggles, defying Ministry legislation forbidding involvement.
The British possibly received magical help to win the Crimean War (1853-1856.)
During the American Revolutionary War, the American magical community aided the colonists in their fight for independence.
Becoming involved in Muggle wars does not help Muggles on the whole, but just privileges one group of Muggles over another.
Where wizards did get involved, it was for self-interest (liking one side more, or not wanting their home to be conquered) rather than humanitarian reasons.
For someone living in the wizarding world this is not necessarily a problem. To the contrary, it spares wizards from dealing with many of the problems that Muggles face.
Muggles have the capability to solve their own problems and yet are unwilling to do so. It is unlikely that wizards would be able to force them.
Solving large scale problems in the Muggle world involves solving bureaucracy created by Muggle political and economic institutions that cannot be overcome with magic.
It may not be a matter of forcing them if Muggles are able to see how easily problems can be solved with the use of magic.
Just because something has clear benefits does not mean that people automatically accept it; many medical treatments are refused by people for a variety of reasons.
The magical education system is inadequate.
Hogwarts, the only British wizarding school, has many structural and security problems.
Hogwarts is a socially highly stratified school, which makes for anything but a pleasant school culture.
There are stark separations among students that clearly elevate older students over younger students, for example the right to own brooms, the right to access Hogsmeade, etc.
This system is not imposed out of malice but to ensure the safety of the younger students.
Muggle boarding schools in some parts of the world implement a system of a 'gate pass' which is a signed form the students need to show the school security guards if they want to leave campus.
Students are separated into various houses from First Year and encouraged to compete against each other and work for their house, for example through Quidditch.
The competition among houses even has the potential to poison the atmosphere within houses: students are exposed to peer pressure and treated according to whether they win or lose house points.
Most classes at early years are separated by house which discourages interhouse relationships.
This is particularly pervasive at Hogwarts because the sorting hat assesses each student before placing them in a house. Your house indirectly becomes a measure of your worth.
For example, Gryffindors are assumed to be brave while Slytherins are supposedly cunning.
Treating people as group members means that people can ignore all of the diverse and detailed information associated with individuals. (McGarty, Yzerbyt and Spears. Pg.4)
Each house emphasizes a different, desirable quality and there isn't a value judgement placed on students for belonging to a particular house.
Hufflepuff is often viewed by other students as being the house for less competent wizards and witches.
This suggests that there is a devaluing of the traits of kindness and fairness in Hogwarts.
There is an intense stigma associated with being in Slytherin.
The traits associated with Slytherin house, such as ambition, cunning and self-preservation, are not necessarily negative traits but are viewed as such in Hogwarts.
But this stigma is well-founded. Slytherin House has highly negative attitudes towards Muggle-borns and many of its students have been Dark Wizards.
The stigma only existed because of Slytherin House's history of producing Dark Wizards. This stigma is likely to reduce over the years after Voldemort's defeat.

The stigma against Slytherin is broader than just their association with Dark Wizards. It is born from a view that their attitude is one of superiority, highlighted by things like the fact their password is, at one point, Pure-Blood.
Salazar Slytherin, who helped found Hogwarts, argued that they should only admit pure-bloods to the school.
Students don't only get sorted based on the traits that they have, but also on the traits that they value.
The Sorting Hat considered putting Harry in Slytherin but he was sorted into Gryffindor because he valued bravery over ambition.
Peter Pettigrew was sorted into Gryffindor even though he was not particularly brave, because he valued that trait.

Even though Hermione’s natural strength lies in her brain and studiousness, she sees friendship and bravery as the most important traits in a person. This is why she was sorted into Gryffindor instead of Ravenclaw.
Hogwarts’ sorting is a rigid system that brands and labels students based on the attributes they valued at the young age of eleven.
It is not possible to change your house once you are sorted but values and choices evolve with time.

Sorting children based on certain traits and attributes leads to the making of a self-fulfilling prophecy. Spending seven years in an environment that continuously imposes a certain sets of traits and expectations on you can lead to an internalization of those traits and a difficulty in outgrowing them in later years.
This segregation at Hogwarts hampers socialization and limits interaction to just people of your own house that share your traits, rather than different types of witches and wizards.
Students are not allowed to visit the common room or dormitories of houses that they do not belong to, so are restricted to spending time only with people in their own houses for some periods.

There is a fair amount of diversity even within houses. Although students fit into their respective houses because of a few shared traits, they possess other traits too and are different from each other.
Although Slytherin house has a bad reputation, many smart and good wizards, like Horace Slughorn and Merlin, belonged to it.
Gryffindor has reckless students like James Potter, Sirius Black and Fred and George Weasley but also more serious students like Percy Weasley and Hermione Granger.
The segregation encourages socialization by giving like-minded students easier access to one another.
This segregation gives students an opportunity to interact more closely and bond with people who value and share the same traits.

The House system is good because it gives the young students who have just been separated from their families a new family and the opportunity to form close relationships and support systems in the new, school environment.
Diversity in social groups benefits all students. Learning with a diverse group encourages collaboration and a better understanding of people from different backgrounds.
Only parts of the student experience are segregated by house. Life within the houses doesn't constitute the whole of the students’ social lives at Hogwarts.
Students interact with each other the entire day on a daily basis. They take classes, share the dining hall and visit Hogsmeade with other houses.
Most students seem to spend the overwhelming majority of their time with students from the same house.
The house points system is not fair and encourages divisions amongst the student body.
Many Muggle schools also place students in houses that they compete on behalf of. This does not necessarily have to be a negative and divisive thing.
Friendships and relationships between the houses are common.
Luna Lovegood from Ravenclaw was best friends with Harry, Ron, Hermione, Ginny and Neville, who were all Gryffindors.
Cho Chang, a Ravenclaw, dated Cedric Diggory and, later, Harry Potter. Both were Triwizard champions for other houses.
Many cross-house friendships were formed through Dumbledore's Army.
Slytherins were excluded from Dumbledore's Army.
This is largely true between Gryffindor, Ravenclaw and Hufflepuff. It is not, however, between Slytherin and the other houses.
Competitions incentivise good behaviour and encourage fun, friendly rivalries. They are not a bad thing.
Students are given points for study and good behaviour, while points are removed for rule-breaking and bullying.
Hogwarts competitions do not encourage good behaviour. They are rife with cheating and foul play.
Hogwarts competitions do not encourage fun and friendly rivalries. Slytherins and Gryffindors are known to hate each other, and this is perpetuated through the competition for the House Cup.
Some students are made prefects in Hogwarts and thus clearly elevated above others.
Prefects are a feature of many Muggle schools in the UK and around the world, so this should not be used as a justification to not live in the wizarding world.
There is more choice of schools in the Muggle world so someone could just choose to go elsewhere.
The houses give students an opportunity to develop their greatest strength or most distinctive quality.
Gryffindor house was founded for the bravest, Ravenclaw for the cleverest, Hufflepuff for hard workers, and Slytherin for those with great ambition.

Because all British wizards go to one school, there is less social stratification overall; even if there is internal social stratification within Hogwarts, there is none of the extreme inter-school stratification that is present in the Muggle world.
Many schools in the Muggle world are also stratified through competitions and age specific privileges. This problem is neither unique to, nor worse at, Hogwarts.
Hogwarts' education system is insufficient in many respects.
There is no higher education.
Wizards get specialized training for job positions after they leave school.
Aurors undergo three years of intensive training after school to make sure they are equipped to do their jobs.
New methodologies are not embraced.

When Snape was a Hogwarts student, he made vast improvements to the art of potion-making. But those methods were not incorporated into the teaching curriculum and the previous ways of making potions are still taught.
Hagrid frequently used new and innovative ways to teach Care of Magical Creatures.
It is probably untrue that these methodologies are embraced. Hagrid is not viewed favourably as a teacher by many.
Students at Hogwarts do not take many practical subjects. They do not learn mathematics, science, writing or foreign languages, and learning about the non-magical world is optional.
A solid foundation in mathematics builds analytical skills that are transferable to other subjects. It is therefore unfortunate that Hogwarts students are not taught these skills.
Since English is the main language spoken in the wizarding world of Britain, students ought to learn English grammar and literature while at Hogwarts.
Language classes would be useful to wizards as well as Muggles, given that wizarding communities span the globe.
Students at Hogwarts cannot learn many humanities subjects, like philosophy or sociology, which would help them think about the world.
As is the case with a Muggle child, it would be useful for wizarding students to have a basic understanding of the human body, the functions of the various organs, first aid, nutrition and hygiene.
For students who come from wizarding families, this can mean they never get any education about the Muggle world, which is not very practical and encourages separation between wizards and Muggles.
Students at Hogwarts learn what is practical from the wizarding perspective.
The primary use of subjects like mathematics and sciences is in creating and developing technology. Since the wizarding world uses magic rather than technology, those subjects are not useful.
Knowledge of mathematics is important in functioning as an adult. All people (including wizards) need to interact with the financial system for example.
The level of mathematics needed to function as an adult is of a rudimentary level that is easily taught at home, in the same way that wizards appear to be taught how to read and write.
A poor knowledge of mathematics and currency conversion makes it harder for wizards, for example Mr Weasley, to use Muggle transportation or other services when the need arises.
Students can learn mathematics by taking arithmancy.

Arithmancy is more a form of divination than mathematics, which involves predicting the future with numbers and numerology. It is completely different to Muggle mathematics, which wizards and witches could still benefit from.
Arithmancy is incredibly important in the wizarding world as it studies the magical properties of numbers, which is useful for many aspects of magic, especially Curse Breaking.
Most wizards appear to know rudimentary arithmetic. It is unclear what benefit more advanced Muggle mathematics would have in the wizarding world.
Many professors are incompetent to the point of uselessness.
Professor Trelawney barely teaches her students anything.
The post of Defence Against the Dark Arts teacher enjoys a succession of incompetent teachers like Quirrell, Lockhart, and Umbridge.
Hogwarts' professors do not respect the rules themselves.
The creation of new species is illegal by law (1965 Ban on Experimental Breeding) but Rubeus Hagrid created the Blast-Ended Skrewt.
Professor McGonagall got special permission from Dumbledore to get Harry Potter a Nimbus 2000 even though first years are not allowed to have their own broomsticks at Hogwarts.

Albus Dumbledore encouraged Harry Potter and Hermione Granger to use the Time-Turner for a purpose it was never intended for and to carry out an illegal act by helping Sirius escape from the Ministry.
This seems to be a problem related to the Hogwarts hiring procedure as opposed to an inherent incompetence of all potential teachers.
Official education does not begin until witches and wizards are 11 years old.
Without formal education until the age of 11 (unless they are Muggle-born), most wizards receive less rudimentary education like reading and writing than Muggles.
Since Hogwarts students are expected to read and write extensively for their assignments, it is likely that they have adequate prior training in reading and writing.
Children of wizarding families sometimes attend a Muggle primary school prior to magical education, but otherwise are home schooled until they are 11.
Putting wizarding children in Muggle schools risks the Muggle children's safety, since wizarding children often do magic by accident or because they do not know better.
Children often use magic accidentally in response to feeling angry, scared or confused. This often has disastrous consequences.
Harry Potter accidentally caused his cousin's aunt to magically inflate and float away when she insulted his late parents.
Ariana Dumbledore killed her mother in an explosion of accidental magic.
Harry Potter accidentally let a boa constrictor free while in the zoo.
Putting wizarding children in Muggle schools risks the exposure of the wizarding world.
Given that the point of magical education is to train them in using magic, it would not be practical to begin this earlier as they are likely to struggle with spells memorisation and completion.
The issues faced by Hogwarts are issues shared across British schools, and are not unique to the magical education system.
Students are not taught essential subjects such as Maths and Literature.
Literature can help build critical thinking skills, which are important for everyone.
Maths helps foster abstract and spatial thinking.
Subjects such as math and literature are essential to Muggles, not wizards.
Arithmancy, the wizard's equivalent of math, is necessary for calculating probabilities of an event. Math itself is useless in the magical world.
Subjects are taught in order to acquire different skills more than information. The skills needed in the life of young wizard are different from those needed in the lives of a young muggle.
Student well-being is not a high priority in magical education.
The Tri Wizard Tournament would be considered child abuse were muggle children subjected to it.
Following significant events, such as the death of a loved one, there are little to no psychological supports available to students.
Students at Hogwarts are exposed to inspirational thoughts about their mental health through their headmaster, Albus Dumbledore.

Parents are forced to choose between either home schooling or boarding school for their children. For parents who do not have the necessary knowledge or skills to educate their children this means that they have no choice at all in whether they see their children for the majority of the year.
Muggle-born students are removed from their friends and family and put in a boarding school where their background is looked down upon.
Electricity and other Muggle equipment do not work in Hogwarts therefore extinguishing easy communication between Muggle-born children and their parents.
Muggle-borns are often treated with disdain and called slanderous names such as 'Mudblood'.
Those using this word to describe Muggle-borns are usually met with social disgust, much like reactions to those Muggles that use the N-word to describe others of black ancestry.
Even in the last moments of his life, Albus Dumbledore reprimands Draco Malfoy for using the term 'Mudblood' in his presence.
After inheriting Kreacher, Harry Potter commands the house-elf to not use the word 'Mudblood' in front of the Muggle-born Hermione Granger.
When Draco Malfoy called Hermione Granger a Mudblood, he was nearly attacked by several members of the Gryffindor Quidditch team and was nearly cursed by Ronald Weasley.
The oppression faced by Muggle-born wizards is no worse than that faced by many disadvantaged communities in the Muggle world.
There are epithets in the Muggle world like the N-word in relation to the black community which are similar to 'Mudblood' associated with having a Muggle heritage.
Muggle-borns are rarely called Mudbloods throughout the Harry Potter series.

There are wizards from magical bloodlines who see Muggle-borns' backgrounds as fascinating, impressive and/or just as valuable as their own. Examples include Albus Dumbledore, Remus Lupin, Arthur Weasley and Sirius Black.

Muggle-born students are offered a place at Hogwarts which they may accept or decline as they and their families see fit. Thus, those Muggle-borns who do enrol must be assumed to have done so voluntarily, having judged that the pros of attending a magical boarding school outweigh the cons of leaving their previous day-to-day life.
At the age of 11, Muggle-borns are below the age of consent and thus cannot properly weigh up the costs and benefits.
The parents of the potential Muggle-born students are introduced into the world of magic as well, to help in making the decision to join Hogwarts and the magical world.
Special messengers are assigned the post to deliver the acceptance letter from Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry to Muggle-born people and to explain the existence of magic.
Severus Snape informed Lily Evans about Hogwarts and told her to expect someone from the school to come by her house to explain to her parents the existence of magic.
Hermione Granger's parents knew about and endorsed her attendance at Hogwarts.
Being non-magical, Muggle parents are also in a vulnerable position when taking the decision to send their child to Hogwarts.
Muggle parents have little idea about what life after education at Hogwarts would be like and if that life is what is best for their children.
Muggle Parents are unaware of the dangers studying at Hogwarts poses for their children.
Muggle parents are unable to comprehend the harms related to the misuse of magic and the Dark Arts.
It seems unlikely that, when presented with the option of learning magic, many 11 year olds would turn down that chance.
The Mahoutokoro School of Japan does not require its younger students to board as it accepts day students from the ages of seven to eleven, though it is required thereafter.
Eleven is still a young age to be separated from one's family.
Only those living near the school will have this option.
The distance from school to home is not a limiting factor to wizarding families as they have access to magical methods of transportation.
While the system could benefit from diversification, it seems to produce functional, reasonably well-adapted citizens of the community which it serves.
You get to go to Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry and learn magic.
At Hogwarts your magical education is fully funded by the Ministry of Magic.
You still need to buy books, robes, a wand and equipment (quill, parchment, cauldron) to go to Hogwarts.
Though familiars are optional to bring to Hogwarts, many students appear to have one, and as such many students may feel like they too must buy one in order to fit in.
This is also true in the Muggle world where students are required to pay for supplies and uniforms even if tuition itself is free.
You can also do exchange programs with wizarding schools around the world, such as Castelobruxo in Brazil.
Exchange programs are also available in the Muggle world and are more ubiquitous as there are more schools to go to.

The Hogwarts curriculum emphasizes putting textbook knowledge into practice. Students routinely transform objects in Transfiguration, brew potions and learn defenses against Dark spells and Dark creatures. They also have to demonstrate their practical abilities to earn good grades in the OWLs and NEWTs.
Not everyone goes to Hogwarts or similar schools.
Hogwarts only accepts students from the UK and Ireland.
Most countries in the world do not have their own wizarding school.
The many easy methods of travel within the wizarding world makes it easy for students to attend schools in other countries, if their country does not have one of its own.

There's a whole host of things you have to consider while sending your child abroad such as your child being in an alien environment, cultural differences between the populations and the difficulty you would face in keeping in touch with your child's life. Therefore it is unlikely that just because travel arrangements can be more easily made, that wizarding parents would be more likely to send their young children across the world for education.
The wizarding population is small and likely does not have the demand for more schools than already exist.
There are a number of other wizarding schools throughout the world.
The flipside is that Hogwarts becomes a de-facto prison which cannot be left without explicit permission and usually only to visit Hogsmeade for a few hours.
Many Muggle boarding schools also don't allow students to leave the premises without permission during the school term for reasons of safety and liability.
The wizarding world is socially regressive.
Love and relationships are treated in a backwards and narrow-minded manner.
The gathering of experience with multiple partners - "relationship shopping" - is apparently not common.
Many wizarding couples marry at a young age.
Lily and James Potter married at eighteen and had their son, Harry, at the age of twenty.
Molly and Arthur Weasley were married before the age of twenty and had their first child by the age of twenty-one.
Fleur Delacour was twenty when she married Bill Weasley.
Harry Potter, Ginny Weasley, Hermione Granger, Ronald Weasley and Draco Malfoy got married in their early 20s or before that.

Most wizards and witches only rushed into marriage after the First Wizarding War in the worry that they may not be able to do it in the near future lest they were killed, as mentioned by Molly Weasley. This may not have been the norm in normal times.
Remus Lupin was thirty-seven when he married Nymphadora Tonks.
However, Nymphadora Tonks was twenty-four when she got married.
Remus Lupin had to wait much longer than others to find a suitable relationship because of the social stigma and physical dangers associated with his being a werewolf.
Some members of the magical community never move beyond their first love even after things do not work out, for example Severus Snape and Albus Dumbledore.
Muggles can also find it difficult or impossible to get over their first love.
Many marriages evolve out of the partners' first serious relationship, for example those of Harry and Ron as well as their respective parents.
Ronald Weasley dated Lavender Brown before getting together with Hermione Granger. Hermione Granger briefly dated Victor Krum before Ron.
Given that many of these relationships seem to be successful in the long term (Hermione and Ron, Harry and Ginny), this is not necessarily a negative thing.
Many Muggles switch partners regularly without finding someone they wish to remain with long-term.
At least anecdotally, divorces and unsuccessful marriages seem to be rare in the wizarding world.
Low divorce rates are not necessarily a sign of healthy relationships. It is equally plausible that marriage laws are conservative and keep failing marriages together.
Ginny Weasley dated Michael Corner and Dean Thomas before Harry Potter. Harry had a crush on Cho Chang and briefly dated her before Ginny.

This is not necessarily something that is discouraged in the Muggle world either, with people who remain with and marry their 'high school sweethearts' or first partner are often idealised and seen as romantic.
Inbreeding with pure-bloods is a common practice for elite wizarding families wanting to uphold the tradition of marrying only wizards of respected ancestry.
The Black, Malfoy, Lestrange and Gaunt families were all notorious for inbreeding among cousins and other relatives.

The Malfoy family is known for marrying outside the pure-blood circle for the purposes of social advancement and to keep their blood from becoming enfeebled or unstable, unlike the Gaunts and Lestranges.
This is not that different from the deliberate or circumstantial associative mating patterns of the Muggle world.
There are many Muggle cultures and communities in which cousin marriage is considered ideal and actively encouraged.

Since a person's ancestry is not relevant in determining substantive features about that person, the fact that pure-bloods breed with each other doesn't actually decrease the diversity of the wizarding world.

There are many people in the Muggle community who still hold narrow-minded views about love, believing that marriage should only be for heterosexual couples or that individuals should abstain from sex until marriage, so this is not unique to the wizarding world.
Same-sex sexual contact is a criminal offence in a total of 74 countries in the Muggle world.
Fornication is illegal in 13 countries in the Muggle world.
Some patriarchal structures still seem to exist in the wizarding world. For example, family structures still suggest women are the homemakers, while the men are the breadwinners.
The women always appear to take their husband's name when they marry. This suggests many patriarchal structures still exist, even if witches have more opportunities than Muggle women.
This was true during Harry Potter's adolescence in the 90's, when most Muggles did the same. Things have changed in the Muggle world and may well have done so in the wizarding world.
Hermione Granger appears to keep her own surname after her marriage to Ron Weasley, with the pair's childrens' surname being Granger-Weasley.
This is an exceptional circumstance and not the norm at all in the wizarding world.

Narcissa Malfoy, Molly Weasley and Lily Potter are all stay-at-home mothers while their husbands work. Comparatively, witches who are career focused are often childless e.g. Minerva McGonagall and Dolores Umbridge.
This suggests there are still limits on what witches are able to achieve, and possibly prejudices and stereotypes that make them choose between family and career.
Women like Professor McGonagall and Sprout show that women don’t have to conform to patriarchal expectation of tending to a family to be considered reputable in the wizarding world.
Additionally, these mothers (more so than their husbands) fit the stereotype of being highly protective of and absolutely devoted to their children, even in war and into death.

While Tonks was criticised for leaving Teddy to fight in the Battle, no one criticised her husband Lupin, who also left his son to participate, despite the fact that Tonks was an Auror and so particularly trained for this situation.

The dynamics in Voldemort's attack on the Potter household are heavily gendered. James, the male, goes to fight him off and protect Lily and Harry, and it is only after James is killed that Lily is put in danger.
Molly Weasley dueled and killed Bellatrix Lestrange after the latter's killing curse narrowly missed Molly's daughter, Ginny.
The devotion seen here is not unique to women, Harry has a similar reaction following the death of Sirius.
If anything, this opposes the notion of patriarchal structures as women are seen as equally prevalent in combat.
This could be a function of the love the parents have for their children, not because of set stereotypes.
While Arthur Weasley and Lucius Malfoy appear to love their children, it is their wives who display the most willingness to risk their own safety for that of their children.
Narcissa Malfoy defied Voldemort's orders and sought Snape's help when Draco was given the task of assassinating Albus Dumbledore.
During the battle of Hogwarts, Narcissa Malfoy risked lying to Lord Voldemort in front of the Death Eaters about Harry's death when she found out from Harry that Draco was alive.
Arthur Weasley risked his life for the safety or betterment of his family on a number of occasions.
Arthur Weasley fought in the Battle of the Astronomy Tower as well as the Second Battle of Hogwarts that threatened the safety of his entire family and the wizarding world at large.
Arthur Weasley was one of the guard members attacked during the Battle of the Seven Potters. He was in charge of his son Fred's safety during the battle.
Arthur Weasley risked his life on guard duty at the Department of Mysteries trying to protect the prophecy.
Most of Arthur Weasley's bravery came when he was working for the Order of the Phoenix, not in the direct protection of his children.

The tasks Arthur Weasley performed on behalf of the Order were not only dangerous but also actively undermined the activity of Lord Voldemort and his Death Eaters who posed an existential threat to the entire wizarding world including all members of the Weasley family.
Molly Weasley takes a more active and assertive role at the Order Headquarters when the battle against Lord Voldemort becomes more overt. It is possible that she chose to be a stay-at-home mother.
Alice Longbottom was an accomplished Auror and a family woman.
Most male professors, like Horace Slughorn, Severus Snape and Rubeus Hagrid, are also childless.
This appears to change over time, as in the Muggle world. Both Ginny Weasley and Hermione Granger have successful careers as well as raising children.
When Harry, Ron and Hermione are searching for Horcruxes, Hermione complains that she is always left to sort the food and suggests it is because she is a girl.

Ron denies the accuracy of this suggestion by claiming the reason she is left to sort the food is because she is the best with magic and therefore the most likely to be able to magically turn their ingredients into something edible.
This is not exclusive to the wizarding world. Many patriarchal structures still exist in the Muggle world as well.
Women are not only represented in the traditional roles of schoolgirls, mothers, and teachers but also in more non-traditional roles.
Many witches are employed at the Ministry of Magic and hold important jobs.

Hermione Granger became the Minister for Magic after serving as the Deputy Head of the Department of Magical Law Enforcement and working at the Department for the Regulation and Control of Magical Creatures.
Amelia Susan Bones was the Head of the Department of Magical Law Enforcement and had a seat on the Wizengamot.
Mafalda Hopkirk worked in the Improper Use of Magic Office and was responsible for the important task of sending out warnings when magic was used by underage wizards or witches.
Dolores Umbridge served as the Head of the Improper Use of Magic Office and Senior Undersecretary to the Minister for Magic.
Women such as Nymphadora Tonks have been aurors.
Many books that are taught at Hogwarts, such as The Standard Book of Spells by Miranda Goshawk and A History of Magic by Bathilda Bagshot, are written by witches.
There are also female healers.
Two of the four heads of houses at Hogwarts, Minerva Mcgonagall and Pomona Sprout, are accomplished women.
Hogwarts was founded in the 10th century by two wizards and two witches. The four founders were highly regarded as the most brilliant witches and wizards of the time.
Witches are often seen as sports heroes.
Quidditch is the most popular sport in the wizarding world and women play on the teams that compete for the Quidditch World Cup and at Hogwarts.

It can be assumed that the captains select these female players based on merit alone rather than some school gender policy as the Slytherin team is permitted to play without any witches on their team.
The Holyhead Harpies is an all-female Quidditch team that plays in the British and Irish Quidditch League.
Moran and Mullet, the Irish Chasers that impressed Harry Potter at the 1994 Quidditch World Cup with their coordinated movements, were witches.
Female players are also given the opportunity to captain Quidditch teams, as Angelina Johnson was in her final year at Hogwarts.
Angelina Johnson, Katie Bell and Ginny Weasley were all key players for the Gryffindor Quidditch team at Hogwarts.
The question is not whether there are some women in non-traditional roles but whether, on the whole, traditional roles dominate. These examples seem to be the exception rather than the rule.
Even if the wizarding world lacks the traditional forms of prejudice that are features of the Muggle world, the wizarding world has its own (often stronger) prejudices.
The wizarding world is very exclusive and sometimes treats those who are not a part of it very cruelly.
Many Death Eaters view harming Muggles as a form of sport.
There are laws which protect Muggles against cruelty by wizards.

The Misuse of Muggle Artefacts Office department was created at the Ministry of Magic to regulate the use of magic on Muggle objects and to try to keep items that had been bewitched away from Muggles.
The Muggle Protection Act, partially written by Arthur Weasley, is a Ministry of Magic by-law that was designed to protect Muggles from potentially harmful magical artifacts.
Wizards found in breach of these laws are dealt with severely, often being sentenced to Azkaban.
The Death Eaters by no means represent the mainstream or the majority of the wizarding world. They acted against the law and were accordingly hunted down.

While this is true, the Death Eaters merely represented the most extreme faction of a conservative group. While others may not have gone to the extent of committing violence against Muggles, it does not mean they did not hold these latent prejudices.
Even the Minister for Magic, Cornelius Fudge, favoured pure-bloods and showed little respect for Squibs and 'half-breeds'.
Racism exists within the wizarding world based on purity of blood.
Many witches and wizards who believe in the importance of blood purity consider half-bloods to be inferior because of their Muggle heritage.
Squibs, non-magical people with at least one magical parent, are looked upon with a degree of disdain by some witches and wizards.
For a long time, policies and attitudes reflected the view that pure-blood wizards and witches were superior to Muggle-borns or half-bloods.
It was not until Hermione Granger became a high ranking member of the Department of Magical Law Enforcement, in the early 2000s, that pro-pure-blood laws were eliminated.
The wizarding world is often classist, xenophobic, racist, and ableist.
Many creatures are actively discriminated against and treated as second-class citizens by the magical community despite having their own magic and/or near-human intelligence.
Half-giants are looked down upon as outcasts of society despite having magical blood and the ability to produce magic.
House-elves, despite their capacity for magic and strong intellect, have long been enslaved to the whims of their wizarding masters.
Despite possessing human intelligence, centaurs are classified as Beasts by the Ministry of Magic.
